title: Information Freshness in Dynamic Gossip Networks
authors: Arunabh Srivastava, Thomas Jacob Maranzatto, Sennur Ulukus
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We consider a source that shares updates with a network of n gossiping nodes. The network’s topology switches between two arbitrary topologies, with switching governed by a two-state continuous time Markov chain (CTMC) process. Information freshness is well-understood for static networks. This work evaluates the impact of time-varying connections on information freshness. In order to quantify the freshness of information, we use the version age of information metric. If the two networks have static long-term average version ages of f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>(n) and f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>(n) with f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>(n) ⪡ f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>(n), then the version age of the varying-topologies network is related to f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>(n), f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>(n), and the transition rates in the CTMC. If the transition rates in the CTMC are faster than f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>(n), the average version age of the varying-topologies network is f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>(n). Further, we observe that the behavior of a vanishingly small fraction of nodes can severely impact the long-term average version age of a network in a negative way. This motivates the definition of a typical set of nodes in the network. We evaluate the impact of fast and slow CTMC transition rates on the typical set of nodes.

title:
Challenges in pCO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Measurement: Lessons Learnt from the MINKE Project
authors: Michela Sega, Francesca Rolle, Francesca Durbiano, Stefano Pavarelli, Giancarlo Raiteri, Andrea Bordone, Sue Hartman, Nicholas Roden, Rajesh Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: The project MINKE “Metrology for integrated marine management and knowledge transfer network”, ended in March 2025, aimed to bring together 16 key European marine metrology research infrastructures to create an innovative ‘quality of oceanographic data’ framework, starting from the Essential Ocean Variables (EOVs) as the key parameters to monitor the oceans, and adopting a multidimensional framework of data quality. One of the EOVs that was investigated is the partial pressure of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, which represents an indicator to monitor the course and potential ecological impact of ocean acidification on the biological processes in the oceans. In the present paper, we summarise the key issues and the potential actions to improve the quality of the measurements of $p \mathrm{CO}_{2}$ in the oceans, as well as the challenges to be faced in the upcoming years.

title: Evaluation of the propagation of oil spills in ports through Artificial Neural Networks
authors: Elisa Castro, Giulia Bonanno, Claudio Iuppa, Rosaria Ester Musumeci, Enrico Foti, Federico Roman, Carla Faraci, Luca Cavallaro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: Assessing oil spill propagation in port terminals is crucial for environmental protection. The dynamics of an oil spill are related to several factors, including the type of oil, volume, spill points, prevailing hydrodynamics and environmental conditions, oil trajectory and fate, and the geographical zone of potential impact. A system that enables the rapid monitoring and prediction of oil spill propagation is crucial for addressing incidents quickly and effectively. Stochastic or numerical model approaches can be used. In this sense, implementing technologies that predict the port facilities involved in the propagation of an oil spill can improve future response capabilities to incidents. The primary objective of this work is to utilise Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to address oil spills and improve detection, prediction, and response capabilities, leveraging their ability to analyse large amounts of data and recognise complex patterns. As a case study, this research focuses on the Port of Augusta (Sicily, Italy), one of the most important ports in Italy. Results revealed that using too few training simulations (e.g., 1,000) led to underfitting, while overly complex networks with too many neurons per layer resulted in overfitting and reduced performance. The optimal balance was achieved with 15 neurons per hidden layer and 9,000 training samples, yielding low RMSE values on unseen data and performance comparable to that of larger datasets. This indicates that computational efficiency can be improved without sacrificing accuracy, highlighting the robustness of machine learning approaches for modelling complex coastal phenomena, such as oil spill dispersion.

title: Marine Obstacles Multi-Modal Detection, Classification and Tracking via Camera-LiDAR Late Fusion
authors: Filippo Ponzini, Michele Martelli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: The ability to detect an obstacle at sea and automatically classify it is crucial for effective and safe navigation. This work presents a method to enhance situational awareness in Marine Autonomous Surface Ships (MASS) equipped with multi-sensor perception systems through the late-fusion of data from RGB cameras and LiDAR sensors. The RGB camera data is processed using a pre-trained YOLOv8 object detector. LiDAR data is processed through a clustering-based detection pipeline and each detection is classified using a trained Random Forest Classifier. Multi-modal detection and classification are used to confirm the presence of a moving obstacle, whose position, obtained from the LiDAR sensor, is tracked over time using a Global Nearest Neighbour tracking algorithm based on a Linear Kalman Filter. The presented sensor fusion approach enhances object detection and classification, thereby improving situational awareness and decision-making capabilities in autonomous systems. Each step of the pipeline is explained in detail, and the system is validated on real data recorded in a harbor.

title: Typicality with Feedback
authors: Thomas Sturma, Michèle Wigger
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: The main objective of this paper is to analyze a closed-loop feedback system where a transmitter probes a discrete memoryless channel (DMC) and can adapt its inputs based on the previous channel outputs. We prove that, regardless of the transmitter’s strategy, the conditional type of the outputs given the inputs remains close to the DMC transition law P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Y|X</inf>. This general result enables the study of fundamental limits in certain adaptive systems.As an application, we establish a converse result for an integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) model. In this setting, the transmitter also functions as a radar receiver, aiming to simultaneously transmit a message over the channel and estimate the channel state from the backscattered feedback signals. We show that the fundamental limits of the closed loop system are the same as of the open-loop system where the transmitter can use the feedback signal to estimate the state but not to produce adaptive channel inputs. This result holds as long as the sum of the admissible-average-decoding-error-probability, denoted ϵ, and the admissible-excess-distortion-probability, denoted δ, is below 1, i.e., δ + ϵ < 1.

title: Secure Pinching Antennas-Aided Wireless Communication System
authors: Elmehdi Illi, Marwa Qaraqe
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: In this paper, a robust pinching antenna-based scheme for ensuring secure wireless communication systems is proposed. In the presence of several malicious eavesdroppers targeting the legitimate signal of various genuine users, the designed approach exploits the spatial flexibility of a pinchingantennas system (PAS) composed of several waveguides and pinching antennas to provide secure communication to legitimate nodes. In particular, multiple pinching antennas can be positioned in each waveguide spanning a long distance, providing additional degrees of freedom and flexibility to adjust the channel response with respect to the various users and eavesdroppers. By virtue of semidefinite programming, an optimization problem aiming at optimizing the transmit beamforming to minimize the total transmit power, subject to secrecy constraints, is formulated and solved. The obtained results demonstrate the total transmit power reduction by increasing the number of antennas and waveguides subject to the same secrecy constraints. Furthermore, the proposed scheme outperforms the benchmark one, consisting of an array of co-located transmit antennas at the base station, when either a direct link from the latter to the users is blocked or when the eavesdroppers are located in the line of sight of the legitimate users.

title: The Process of Ice Breaking Water of the Vehicle Fluid-Solid Coupling Dynamics Numerical Simulation
authors: Wenzheng Yang, Yao Shi, Liyan Lan, Shan Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: The dynamic behavior of ice-breaking and waterexit processes is crucial for improving underwater vehicle performance and ensuring polar mission safety. This study investigates ice fragmentation and impact loads during vehicle emergence through floating ice, using a numerical method based on the ALE and penalty function contact algorithms to model the coupled interaction of ice, vehicle, and water. Simulations explore various launch speeds, ice densities, and impact location. Results indicate the process comprises three stages, dominated by hydrodynamic and collision forces, peaking at 1400 kN and 2600 kN, respectively. Higher launch speeds lead to slower velocity decay, with only 5.98% reduction at 50 m/s. Increased ice density raises both force types, with collision forces about half of hydrodynamic ones. Impacting the ice center causes the highest forces and velocity loss; off-center impacts reduce attenuation from 11.44% to 4.18%. These findings offer theoretical and technical insights for underwater launches in polar regions.

title: Evaluating the efficiency of PacBio long-read technology to analyse the diet of alien blue crabs (Callinectes sapidus Rathbun, 1896)
authors: Tamara Lazic, Lucrezia Cilenti, Rita De Giosa, Bruno Fosso, Marinella Marzano, Elisabetta Notario, Graziano Pesole, Cataldo Pierri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: The Atlantic blue crab Callinectes sapidus Rathbun, 1896, widely distributed throughout the Mediterranean Sea, is a non-indigenous species that is characterized by generalist feeding behaviour and adaptability to diverse environmental conditions. As such, it is important to evaluate the species dietary composition to estimate eventual ecological and economic impacts, yet traditional stomach content analysis is often limited in detecting digested and/or softbodied prey. In this study, we developed a protocol and employed a high-resolution DNA metabarcoding approach using COI PacBio-barcoded primers to characterize the diet of C. sapidus from different sites across Apulia, Italy. While most stomachs were found to be empty or contained insufficient material for analysis, intestinal contents provided reliable DNA for downstream processing. Amplification of the mitochondrial cox1 gene was technically successful; however, a high proportion of sequences were of bacterial origin, and few metazoan prey taxa were detected, suggesting that the chosen gene may have limited efficacy in faecal samples due to microbial dominance and/or degraded prey DNA. Nonetheless, taxonomic analysis revealed several prey taxa, including other non-native crab Dyspanopeus sayi. Findings of the present study suggest that PacBio long-read sequencing on faecal samples could represent an efficient methodology, but it should be used in conjunction with optimized extraction procedures and molecular workflows designed to reduce host and microbial DNA dominance.

title: Comparative Security Performance Analysis of DSSS and FHSS in Underwater Acoustic Channels
authors: Khaliq Ur Rahman, Nazila Fough, Christopher D. McDermott, Rida Sundas, Craig Stewart, Somasundar Kannan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: Underwater Acoustic Communication (UAC) is critical for subsea applications but faces challenges from ambient noise and deliberate interference, such as jamming. This study compares the security and performance of baseline 4-Frequency Shift Keying (4-FSK) with two spread spectrum variants, Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS-4FSK) and Frequency-Hopping Spread Spectrum (FHSS-4FSK), under simulated underwater conditions with persistent narrowband interference. Using MATLAB simulations, the systems are evaluated for Bit Error Rate (BER) and throughput to assess reliability and communication integrity. Results demonstrate that DSSS-4FSK and FHSS-4FSK significantly outperform 4FSK, achieving up to $99 \%$ lower BER at signal-to-noise ratios $(S N R) \geq 10 \mathrm{~dB}$, due to their robust interference rejection and low probability of intercept/detection (LPI/LPD) properties. FHSS-4FSK excels against fixed-frequency jamming, while DSSS-4FSK offers potential resilience to broadband interference. These findings highlight the efficacy of spread spectrum techniques for designing secure, reliable UAC systems for mission-critical operations, such as defence and subsea monitoring.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Malicious URL Detection using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Leena Nazzal, Mahmoud Jazzar, Amna Eleyan, Tarek Bejaoui
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Malicious URL detection has become a critical aspect of cybersecurity, as malicious URLs, including phishing, malware distribution, and other malicious activities are increasingly prevalent. Traditional approaches, such as signature-based and rule-based methods, have shown limitations in adapting to evolving threats, highlighting the need for more advanced techniques. This study investigates the application of deep learning techniques, including CNN, LSTM, RNN, GRU, and Transformers, to malicious URL detection. The study explores the performance of these algorithms across different datasets, focusing on the accuracy, strengths, and weaknesses of each approach. This paper identifies key challenges, through a comprehensive analysis of recent studies. In addition, highlight emerging trends, innovations, and gaps in the literature, suggesting potential improvements for future research. The review also discusses future directions, including the development of hybrid models and stacking techniques to enhance accuracy while reducing overfitting. Our work aims to provide a clear understanding of modern deep learning approaches to malicious URL detection and provides important insights for researchers to build more robust and adaptive systems.

title: Example-Based Data Retrieval Using Pattern Analysis Methods
authors: Alexey Myachin
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of example-based object retrieval in high-dimensional databases using pattern analysis methods. We propose a streaming algorithm that computes the rank vector for a given query object and filters database entries by comparing complete rank structures. This enables exact retrieval without constructing complex indices and is fully invariant to scale transformations and measurement units. Experimental results on a synthetic dataset of 1 000 000 objects (8 features, 10 patterns) and on classical datasets demonstrate high speed (up to 0.54 seconds per million objects and fractions of a millisecond on small sets) and low memory usage due to streaming processing. The method is suitable for large streaming repositories where loading the entire dataset into RAM is infeasible.

title: A Hybrid Balancing Method for IDS Datasets Using CTGAN + K-Means
authors: Thanh Tra Ung, Cong Thanh Nguyen, Tan Duy Le, Duy Trung Pham, Thu Lam Bui
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference On Cryptography And Information Security (VCRIS)
abstract: Machine learning and deep learning based intrusion detection systems (IDS) are being used more and more to protect computer networks from complex cyber attacks. However, these systems often do not work well because the training dataset is imbalanced which attack samples make up only a small part of the dataset, while normal samples are much more common. We suggest a method that combines the data generation ability of Conditional Tabular Generative Adversarial Network (CTGAN) and the data reduction ability of K-Means to solve the data imbalance problem in IDS datasets from the Canadian Institute for Cybersecurity (CIC). Our method first merges well-known datasets like CICIDS2017, CSE-CICIDS2018, CICDDoS2019 and CIC-UNSW-NB15 into one unified dataset. Then, K-Means is used to reduce the number of majority class samples (undersampling), while CTGAN is used to create more minority class samples (oversampling). These are combined to make a balanced dataset, which is used to train and test IDS models such as Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), Naive Bayes (NB) and Graph Convolution Network (GCN). Experimental results show that our balance method CTGAN+K-Means performs much better than traditional balancing methods such as SMOTE and ADASYN.

title: BLOCKTAIL: A Large-Size and Efficiently Implemented Bit-Oriented Design for Block Ciphers and Permutations
authors: Hoang Dinh Linh, Nguyen Van Long, Luong Tran Thi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference On Cryptography And Information Security (VCRIS)
abstract: Block ciphers and cryptographic permutations are core primitives in symmetric cryptography, forming the basis of encryption, hashing, authentication, and random number generation. We present BLOCKTAIL, a novel bit-oriented design with a 256-bit state that unifies block cipher and permutation functionality. This approach supports the construction of large, secure, and efficient permutations, suitable for modern frameworks such as Sponge, Duplex, and Farfalle. We analyze the algebraic degree of BLOCKTAIL and show that 9 rounds provide strong resistance against higher-order differential, algebraic, and cube attacks. Implementation results demonstrate that BLOCKTAIL achieves competitive encryption speed and reduced lookup-table size compared to existing efficient ciphers, while maintaining robust security guarantees.

title: On Finite-Blocklength Noisy Classical-Quantum Channel Coding With Amplitude Damping Errors
authors: Tamás Havas, Hsuan-Yin Lin, Eirik Rosnes, Ching-Yi Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We investigate practical finite-blocklength classical–quantum channel coding over the quantum amplitude damping channel (ADC), aiming to transmit classical information reliably through quantum outputs. Our findings indicate that for any finite blocklength, a naive (uncoded) approach fails to offer any advantage over the ADC. Instead, sophisticated encoding strategies that leverage both classical error-correcting codes and quantum input states are crucial for realizing quantum performance gains at finite blocklengths.

title: Wave Field Variability at Model Grid Scale: Results from a Moored Buoy Array Offshore Livorno
authors: Carlo Brandini, Bartolomeo Doronzo, Stefano Taddei, Angelo Boccacci, Luca Centurioni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: This work presents the results of an experimental campaign carried out off the coast of Livorno (Italy) involving a moored array of Directional Wave Spectra Drifter (DWSD) buoys. The aim was to explore the spatial variability of wave parameters at the scale of numerical wave model grids ($\mathbf{1. 5 ~ k m}$ spacing), using a $3 \times 3$ buoy configuration over an area of approximately $9 \mathrm{~km}^{2}$. Each buoy recorded directional spectra at 1 to 3 hour intervals and transmitted data in near real-time via satellite. The deployment, active from November 2022 to April 2023, encountered partial buoy losses but allowed the collection of a unique high-resolution dataset for analysing the spatial coherence and variability of the wave field. The grid configuration was designed to emulate the nodal resolution of operational wave models and to investigate sub-grid variability of key parameters such as significant wave height (Hs), wave period (Tp), and wave direction (Dd). Preliminary analysis highlights strong spatial coherence during swell conditions and more pronounced gradients during mixed or wind-sea events, with implications for the interpretation of in situ data and the quantification of sea-state-dependent uncertainty. Some operational insights are also provided, including lessons learned on mooring stability and data recovery, with brief recommendations for future deployments.

title: Identification of Damaged Coastal Areas starting from newspaper articles in the Canary Islands
authors: Aniello Florio, Daniel Guerra Medina, German Rodriguez Rodriguez, Diana Di Luccio, Guido Benassai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: In this study, we identified coastal areas in the Canary Islands that suffered damage, using historical data from newspapers and existing scientific databases. To this aim, we collected newspaper articles focusing on extreme coastal events that had a significant impact on the shoreline, causing varying degrees of damage. We analyzed 87 coastal sites in the Canary Islands affected by extreme storm events over the past $\mathbf{3 0}$ years. The intensity of the storms was validated using wind and wave data, confirming an annual increase in coastal damage correlated with the rise in wave energy. The findings are intended to improve risk assessment and support the development of mitigation strategies for coastal infrastructure in the region.

title: Cascade PID Control Method for Inner and Outer Loops of Transverse Tilt Bi-Coptor UAV
authors: Liang Zhang, Runyu Cai
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: This study proposes a cascade PID control method with inner-outer loop architecture to address the control challenges of transverse tilting-rotor bicopter UAVs. The research framework encompasses three phases: Dynamic modeling and system integration, Controller development and Experimental validation. Firstly, a simplified dynamic model of the transverse tilt bicopter UAV was established through Newton-Euler equations with fundamental flight mechanics assumptions. Subsequent system integration involved V-frame airframe structure design using SolidWorks CAD platform, followed by selection of avionics components and propulsion systems based on performance requirements for full-scale assembly. Then, a cascade PID controller was developed with, Outer-loop, Position regulation (translational control) and Inner-loop, Attitude stabilization (rotational control). The control architecture was implemented through a Simulinkbased mathematical simulation system, enabling PID parameter optimization via numerical analysis. Finally, physical validation included turntable experiments and hovering flight tests under operational conditions. Both simulation and hardware implementation result conclusively demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed cascade PID control methodology.

title: A Decoder with Reinforcement Learning Feedback
authors: Milad Taghipour, Bane Vasić
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning techniques to improve the performance of bit-flipping decoders and finding their optimal decisions. We begin by providing an overview of bit-flipping based decoders and reinforcement learning algorithms. We then outline the methodology for mapping the iterative decoding process into Markov Decision Processes (MDPs). We propose a feedback-based method to exploit and enhance the performance of existing well-established decoders by applying reinforcement learning algorithms after a selected decoder. In essence, we modify the MDP to reduce the number of states, making reinforcement learning algorithms feasible for low-rate and long-length codes. In addition, focusing on the correction of dominant error patterns of a selected decoder improves its error correction capability. Finally, we present experimental results for the Binary Symmetric Channel (BSC) to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed methods.

title: Research on the Afterbody Integration of BDTN and Exploration of Drag Reduction Methods
authors: Ruifeng PAN, Jinglei XU, Han DONG, Yuqi Zhang, Shuai HUANG
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: The development trend of future combat aircraft capabilities represented by airplanes is wide speed range, high stealth ability, high maneuverability, and high energy. The integration of aircraft and engine is a key technology and development trend for future fighter aircraft. It could prevent a situation where “a suitable engine” is installed on “a suitable aircraft,” yet it forms an “unsuitable system.” Aircraft-engine integration is a critical technology and development trend for future fighter aircraft, with its core lying in the integration of aircraft-engine, structure and control. High-speed aircraft afterbodies generate extensive expansion waves/shock waves, leading to shock wave-boundary layer interactions, flow separation, and other complex flow phenomena, which increase the afterbody drag. The Bypass Dual Throat Nozzle (BDTN) constitutes a category of Fluidic Thrust Vectoring Nozzle (FTVN) characterized by fixed geometry. In contrast to conventional fluidic vectoring nozzles, the BDTN employs internal bypass flow to interact with the primary stream, enabling self-adaptive flow control. Symmetric micro holes incorporated within the convergent section of the cavity leverage the pressure gradient between the high-pressure recirculation zone inside the cavity and the low-pressure region near the wall. This differential pressure induces micro-jet formation. These jets effectively compensate for the low-pressure zone and also act as miniature thrust nozzles, contributing additional thrust. Under typical operating conditions, compared to the baseline configuration: The single-hole jet BDTN reduces pressure drag by up to 60.99% and the drag-thrust ratio by up to 43%. The double-hole jet BDTN reduces pressure drag by up to 74% and the drag-thrust ratio by up to 53%.

title: Dynamic Characteristic Analysis and Optimization Design for Spacecraft Electromechanical Composite Skin Panel Structures
authors: Zhihao Luo, Dongxu Li, Shiyao Zhu, Shenda Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: To resolve the traditional limitations of enhanced functionality inevitably increasing weight and integration inevitably reducing efficiency in spacecraft panel structures, this study proposes a novel electromechanical composite skin panel structure featuring integrated design of Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs) and honeycomb sandwich panels. This structure combines load-bearing, weight reduction, and electronic functions into one entity. Finite element models were established using refined modeling and the sandwich method respectively. Analyses were performed on the influence of five key parameters, including honeycomb core configuration and carbon fiber ply angles, on dynamic characteristics. Under mass constraints, multi-parameter optimization was conducted with the highest fundamental frequency as the objective. The optimized fundamental frequency increased by up to 30% compared to the initial design, achieving a simultaneous breakthrough in structural weight reduction and functional integration.

title: Navigating the LEO Network: A Routing Optimisation Approach
authors: Alice De Guibert, Mohammad Imran Syed, Oana Hotescu, Jérôme Lacan
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) constellations are transforming today’s modern communication era by enabling highspeed, low-latency, and reliable broadband services at a global scale. Despite their huge potential, designing efficient mechanisms for satellite networks is challenging due to the dynamic nature of LEO satellites. In this paper, we focus on routing in LEO constellations including Inter-Satellite Links (ISLs) with several constraints like e.g. minimising the maximum link utilisation. We propose a static approach aiming to find optimal paths to transmit traffic demands in the network graph. We consider Linear Programming (LP) to formulate problems for different network constraints and show that we are able to provide solutions respecting the various constraints, including those related to quality of service (QoS).

title: The Role of Rank in Mismatched Low-Rank Symmetric Matrix Estimation
authors: Panpan Niu, Yuhao Liu, Teng Fu, Jie Fan, Chaowen Deng, Zhongyi Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We investigate the performance of a Bayesian statistician tasked with recovering a rank-k signal matrix SS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">⊤</sup> ∈ ℝ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n×n</sup>, corrupted by element-wise additive Gaussian noise. This problem lies at the core of numerous applications in machine learning, signal processing, and statistics. We derive an analytic expression for the asymptotic mean-square error (MSE) of the Bayesian estimator under mismatches in the assumed signal rank, signal power, and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), considering both sphere and Gaussian signals. Additionally, we conduct a rigorous analysis of how rank mismatch influences the asymptotic MSE. Our primary technical tools include the spectrum of Gaussian orthogonal ensembles (GOE) with low-rank perturbations and asymptotic behavior of k-dimensional spherical integrals.

title: Study on the Effect of Ice Pore Parameters on the Attenuation of Ultrasonic Echo Signals
authors: Siyu Chen, Yuan Wang, Bin Li, Yan Wang, Zhanpeng Ren, Yang Zhang, Qingwen Lu, Chengxiang Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: There are different types of ice accumulated on aircraft in different environments, which is due to the difference in porosity within the ice. The porosity of ice has a significant effect on the attenuation of the ultrasonic pulse-echo signal, which restricts the detection depth when using ultrasonic pulseecho technology to detect aircraft surface ice. In order to obtain the effective detection range of ice thickness with ultrasonic transducer under different ice types, we studied the effect of ice porosity parameters on ultrasonic echo signal attenuation. First, a transducer-aluminum plate-porous ice structure model was established, and the ultrasonic propagation in multi-layer media and the attenuation characteristics of porous ice were theoretically studied. Then, an ultrasonic icing detection experimental platform in a cold environment was set up. The ice with different pore characteristics was prepared, and the ultrasonic detection signals at different frequencies were recorded. The pore parameters of the impact ice samples obtained by scanning through a microscope were analyzed. After that, the attenuation of the waveforms at different frequencies was analyzed. Finally, the correlation between the attenuation coefficient and frequency was obtained. The experimental results show that the growth of porosity within the ice is directly proportional to the attenuation of the ultrasonic signal at different frequencies; the attenuation coefficients of the ultrasonic signal at the same porosity grow with the growth of the frequency. And the frequency-dependent detection ranges of ice thickness for each ice type are given.

title: Poster: Power Out, Internet Down? Measuring Internet Resilience in South Africa
authors: Yasin Alhamwy, Abdalmohimn Alshebane, Oliver Hohlfeld
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 ACM Internet Measurement Conference
abstract: South Africa's frequent electricity outages—both planned and unplanned—not only disrupt daily life but also impact Internet infrastructure in this critical regional connectivity hub. This study analyses the relationship between power outages and Internet resilience by correlating end-user performance metrics, amateur radio activity, and BGP routing data with detailed outage records. We find that network performance degrades only during unplanned outages, revealing heightened vulnerability during unexpected events. Amateur radio activity shows a weak negative correlation with both planned and unplanned outages, while BGP announcement patterns vary, showing both positive and negative correlations depending on the month. These results show how outage types shape connectivity and give us a deeper insight into the resilience of the Internet in South Africa.

title: Poster: Measuring Algorithmic Systems' Resilience Against Generative AI-Powered Attacks -- Case Study on Exploiting a Code Search Platform
authors: Nathaniel Hahn, Tu Ouyang, An Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 ACM Internet Measurement Conference
abstract: Generative AI applications have boomed since the GPT-3-powered ChatGPT release in 2022. Miscreants also see the opportunities of leveraging these frontier GenAI technologies to facilitate cyberattacks, from planning to execution.

title: Poster: Learning to Personalize in Federated Networks with Contribution-Aware Aggregation
authors: Ke Xing, Yanjie Dong, Xiaoyi Fan, Xiping Hu
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Personalized Federated Learning (PFL) targets client-specific models under heterogeneous and limited data. However, conventional methods often use heuristic or data-size-based averaging and overlook the true contributions of client updates. We propose a contribution-oriented PFL framework that quantifies client contributions via gradient alignment and prediction discrepancy for informed aggregation. We further develop a parameter-wise personalization mechanism for adaptive local updates and a mask-aware momentum optimizer for stable training. Preliminary results on CIFAR10 validate its effectiveness.

title: Demo: Task Cooperation for Urban Unmanned Sanitation Vehicles
authors: Lingzi Zhao, Feng Lyu, Hao Wu, Huaqing Wu, Huali Lu, Shucheng Li, Tao He, Wenlong Liao, Sheng Zhong
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Unmanned sanitation vehicles (USVs) promise cleaner cities, yet efficiently coordinating multiple USVs in large urban areas remains challenging due to constraints such as limited waste capacity and battery life. In this demo, we present MRTC, a multi-robot task cooperation system. First, Dynamic Task Assignment employs an Actor-Critic policy within a Markov decision framework to allocate cleaning tasks and decide the required number of USVs. Second, Single-USV Path Planning refines each route via a fast two-layer iterative search. Over an eight-month real-world deployment in three urban testbeds, our MRTC system markedly improved cleaning efficiency while lowering operating costs. Operating over a combined 10,775 km of routes per month, the system achieved average monthly savings of 20,575 kWh of energy and 2,744 labour hours. A demonstration video is available at https://llq978.github.io/Demo/.

title: Demo: Split-and-Pipeline: Collaborative Large Model Inference on Edge Devices
authors: Zuguang Li, Dongyuan Ou, Wen Wu, Songge Zhang, Shaohua Wu, Xuemin (Sherman) Shen
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Deploying and executing large model inference on edge devices is challenging due to their limited computational power and memory resources. To address this challenge, we present a novel Split-and-Pipeline, a collaborative inference scheme that partitions a large model into multiple submodels and executes them across distributed edge devices in a pipelined manner. The scheme parallelizes data transfer across multiple CPU cores to avoid transmission bottlenecks. We build a real-world testbed using NVIDIA Jetson series edge devices to demonstrate the proposed scheme, achieving 1.2×–3.0× throughput improvement over state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Cross-Technology Sensing: Leveraging LoRa Signals to Empower WiFi Sensing
authors: Binbin Xie, Weizheng Wang, Deepak Ganesan, Lili Qiu, Jie Xiong
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Various wireless technologies have been utilized for sensing. Although promising, these wireless sensing technologies have inherent limitations. Prior research mainly focuses on overcoming the limitations of an individual wireless sensing technology, and little attention has been paid to the potential benefits of sensing with more than one wireless technology. In this paper, we introduce the concept of cross-technology sensing for the first time, and propose LoFiSen to enable LoRa-to-WiFi sensing. LoFiSen leverages the strengths of both LoRa and WiFi—combining LoRa's long-range capability with WiFi's pervasiveness. The chirp characteristic of LoRa signal significantly improves the sensing range of WiFi, and the widespread availability of WiFi devices makes LoRa sensing more pervasive. LoFiSen is fully compatible with LoRa and WiFi protocols, and can work on commodity LoRa and WiFi hardware. The key component of our design is enabling the WiFi receiver to capture fine-grained LoRa signal variations for sensing. Real-world experiments demonstrate that LoFiSen improves the WiFi sensing range for respiration monitoring from 8 m to 41 m, and pushes the walking sensing range from 16 m to 73.5 m. Through-wall passive respiration monitoring, previously infeasible with state-of-the-art WiFi sensing, is now possible with LoFiSen.

title: Making LoRa Sensing Coexist with Communication
authors: Binbin Xie, Minhao Cui, Deepak Ganesan, Jie Xiong
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: LoRa-based contact-free wireless sensing has attracted a lot of attention owing to its long sensing range, enabling wide-area sensing for the first time. While promising, existing LoRa sensing assumes there is no communication going on which is usually not true. We observe a severe degradation of sensing performance in real-world settings in the presence of communication. This issue hinders LoRa sensing from being adopted in real life and being integrated into the already established LoRa networking infrastructure. In this paper, we propose LSencom which takes the first step toward making LoRa-based wireless sensing work in the presence of communication. The key design is to employ the reversed chirp, i.e., downchirp, for sensing while keeping the original upchirp for communication. This design smartly leverages the orthogonality between downchirp and upchirp to mitigate the interference between communication and sensing. While the upchirp-downchirp design can remove most of the interference, we further adopt a novel chirp rotation method to deal with the remaining power leakage interference from upchirp to downchirp, enhancing the sensing performance. We implement LSencom on commodity LoRa nodes. Real-world experiments demonstrate that LSencom can reduce the communication-induced interference on sensing by 22.3 dB, and enable LoRa sensing even in the presence of multiple communication links.

title: MetaGuardian: Enhancing Voice Assistant Security through Advanced Acoustic Metamaterials
authors: Zhiyuan Ning, Zheng Wang, Zhanyong Tang
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Voice assistants (VAs) have become integral to daily life, yet their always-on microphones make them attractive targets for attacks that threaten user privacy and safety. We present MetaGuardian, the first system to leverage acoustic metamaterials to defend against three major classes of attacks for VAs - inaudible, adversarial, and laser-based - within a single, portable design. Unlike prior defenses, MetaGuardian can be seamlessly integrated into the enclosures of commercial smart devices, providing strong protection without requiring software modification, hardware redesign, or costly machine learning models. MetaGuardian leverages mutual impedance effects between metamaterial units to extend the protection range to 16–40 kHz, effectively blocking wideband inaudible attacks. It also employs a carefully designed coiled space structure to disrupt adversarial signals while preserving normal VA operations. Its universal design allows flexible adaptation to different devices, striking a balance between portability and protection effectiveness. In controlled evaluations, MetaGuardian achieves a high defense success rate across all attack types, offering a practical and reliable foundation for securing VAs on smart devices.

title: Transfer Learning for Cross-Domain Sentiment Classification via Domain Adaptation
authors: Rahul Kumar Singh, Agampreet Saini, Erik Cambria, Abhijit Kumar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: The exponential proliferation of user-generated content across online platforms has driven a substantial surge in domain-specific textual data. Consequently, sentiment analysis has emerged to facilitate context-aware, real-time decision making in dynamic, data-intensive domains. Nevertheless, obtaining large-scale annotated data for all domains remains impractical, therefore a necessity for robust cross-domain sentiment classification techniques is still necessary. This work proposes WBiGe a hybrid domain adaptation architecture that combines static and contextual embeddings with a hierarchical BiGRU encoder to exploit semantic structure globally and sentiment cues locally. A lightweight convolutional architecture is used to extract phrase level patterns that are usually ignored by sequential encoders to improve short range sentiment expressions detection. To focus sentiment informative pivots and nonpivots during domain drilldown, a class aware domain alignment mechanism based on weighted maximum mean discrepancy is utilized. Furthermore, an iterative pseudolabeling strategy and dual-level attention modules are incorporated into the architecture to continuously improve target domain prediction to increase the interpretability of the model. The proposed WBiGe framework was extensively assessed using the Amazon benchmark dataset, in which it significantly outperforms the existing models across a wide range of cross-domain classification tasks with a record peak accuracy of 92.75%.

title: A Novel Indicator for Robust On-Line Inter-Turn Fault Detection in Induction Machines Considering Winding Connections, Voltage Unbalance and Load Variation
authors: Mouhamed Houili, Mohamed Sahraoui, Khaled Laadjal, Antonio J. Marques Cardoso, Abdeldjalil Alloui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: Induction machines are critical in industrial processes due to their robustness and reliability. However, undetected inter-turn short-circuit (ITSC) faults can lead to significant damage and economic losses. This paper presents a novel, real-time method for early ITSC fault detection in induction motors, applicable to both star and delta winding connections and robust under unbalanced supply voltage (USV) and varying load conditions. The method introduces a new fault indicator, the Negative Admittance Factor (NYF), defined as the ratio of negative to positive sequence admittance components. These components are estimated using the Fortescue transform applied to three-phase current and voltage measurements processed via the Short-Time Least Squares Prony (STLSP) method. Experimental validation on a 1.1 kW induction motor demonstrates the NYF’s effectiveness in detecting even low-severity ITSC faults under diverse operating conditions. The proposed method, implemented in LabVIEW, offers a practical and reliable solution for enhancing the safety and reliability of induction motor applications.

title: FPGA Implementation of a Real-Time Parallel Loop-Unrolled DFE for PAM-4 IM/DD Optical Links
authors: Jianyu Wang, Jianwei Tang, Yaguang Hao, Yingying Zhou, Xiuquan Cui, Linsheng Fan, Zhongliang Sun, Junpeng Liang, Zhaopeng Xu, Weisheng Hu, Zhixue He, Yanfu Yang, Jinlong Wei
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: This work presents a novel hardware-efficient FPGA implementation of a real-time parallel loop-unrolled decision feedback equalizer (DFE) for PAM-4 IM/DD optical links. The proposed DSP architecture integrates timing recovery, a 5-tap FFE, and a novel single-tap parallel DFE leveraging an 8×8 loop-unrolled structure and a hardware-friendly error-based tap update mechanism thus effectively reduces processing complexity and clock delay. The implementation occupies only 4.2% LUTs, 2.75% FFs, and 6.8% DSP48E2 resources of a Xilinx XCVU13P chip. A successful 29.4912 Gb/s real-time PAM-4 signal transmission over a 10 km SSMF is demonstrated using a cost-effective directly modulated laser (DML) and achieving a BER below the 7% HD-FEC threshold, indicating a scalable and efficient solution for high-speed short reach optical data links.

title: Study on the Improving the Uniformity of Ti Distribution in New Type of High J c Nb 3 Sn Wire Produced by WST
authors: Jianya Chen, Haijun Su, Qiang Guo, Zheng Li, Yigong Shi, Bo Wu, Xianghong Liu, Yong Feng, Jianfeng Li, Pingxiang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: High Jc Nb3Sn superconducting wires is mainly used in the preparation of high field magnets because of its higher critical current density. Further improving the critical current density of Nb3Sn wire, reducing the use amount of wire in magnets is one of important ways to promote the industrialization and mass application of High Jc Nb3Sn wire. It is known that doping Ti in Nb3Sn phase can improve the critical magnetic field effectively, refine the Nb3Sn grains, and improve the critical current density. Too much or too little Ti will greatly reduce the doping effect. The Ti diffusion is later than the Nb3Sn phase reaction under three-zone section heat treatment, so the distribution of Ti in Nb3Sn phase is uneven. This paper introduces a new heat treatment process, which can improve the uniformity of Ti in Nb3Sn phase by adding an insulation platform between the medium temperature and high temperature insulation platform. Eventually, the critical current density of the High Jc Nb3Sn wire was improved, reaching 2938 A/mm2.
