title: TiVy: Time Series Visual Summary for Scalable Visualization
authors: Gromit Yeuk-Yin Chan, Luis Gustavo Nonato, Themis Palpanas, Cláudio T. Silva, Juliana Freire
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Visualizing multiple time series presents fundamental tradeoffs between scalability and visual clarity. Time series capture the behavior of many large-scale real-world processes, from stock market trends to urban activities. Users often gain insights by visualizing them as line charts, juxtaposing or superposing multiple time series to compare them and identify trends and patterns. However, existing representations struggle with scalability: when covering long time spans, leading to visual clutter from too many small multiples or overlapping lines. We propose TiVy, a new algorithm that summarizes time series using sequential patterns. It transforms the series into a set of symbolic sequences based on subsequence visual similarity using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW), then constructs a disjoint grouping of similar subsequences based on the frequent sequential patterns. The grouping result, a visual summary of time series, provides uncluttered superposition with fewer small multiples. Unlike common clustering techniques, TiVy extracts similar subsequences (of varying lengths) aligned in time. We also present an interactive time series visualization that renders large-scale time series in real-time. Our experimental evaluation shows that our algorithm (1) extracts clear and accurate patterns when visualizing time series data, (2) achieves a significant speed-up (1000ttttttttttttttttttttttttttt) compared to a straightforward DTW clustering. We also demonstrate the efficiency of our approach to explore hidden structures in massive time series data in two usage scenarios.

title: Multi-Modal Broadcast Packet Erasure Channels: Capacity with Non-Stationary Controllable Statistics
authors: Alireza Vahid, Shih-Chun Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: In several wireless settings, channel statistics may be controllable and/or predictable. For instance, next generation reconfigurable antennas have the potential to control channel statistics. Further, the known trajectory and operation protocol of communication satellites results in networks with predictable statistics. These settings give rise to a non-stationary model for which the fundamentals are largely unknown. We consider the canonical two-user broadcast packet erasure channel in which channel statistics vary at a priori known points in time. We consider a multi-modal setting with two non-transient modes (whose lengths scale linearly with the blocklength) and an arbitrary number of transient modes. We provide a new set of outer-bounds on the capacity region of this problem when the encoder has access to causal feedback. The results reveal the significant role of the non-transient mode with higher erasure probability both on the outer and the inner bounds. We show the outer-bounds are achievable in non-trivial regimes, characterizing the capacity region for a wide range of parameters. We also discuss the regimes where the inner and outer bounds diverge and analyze the gap between the two. A key finding of this work is the significant gain of inter-modal coding over the separate treating of individual modes.

title: An Efficient GPU-Based Halpern Accelerating Algorithm for Large-Scale DC Optimal Power Flow
authors: Qi Wang, Guojun Zhang, Yue Yang, Chao Ren, Wenchuan Wu, Xinyuan Zhao, Mikael Skoglund, Defeng Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: With numerous renewable generators and energy storage systems integrated into the power grids, the security-constrained DC optimal power flow (DCOPF) is essential for power system operation. For large-scale power grids, traditional CPU-based optimization algorithms (such as the simplex and barrier methods) have saturated in computational efficiency and are inherently difficult to parallelize. To tackle these issues, by incorporating the symmetric Gauss–Seidel (sGS) decomposition, this work develops a GPU-based Halpern Peaceman-Rachford algorithm, termed the sGS-HPR, which enjoys an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(1/k)$</tex-math></inline-formula> iteration complexity in terms of the KKT residual. Moreover, the closed-form solutions for all subproblems are derived, which only consist of matrix- vector multiplications and vector operations, and thus can be easily parallelized on GPUs. As a consequence, the developed sGS-HPR algorithm enjoys a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O({N_{L} \times n} / \epsilon)$</tex-math></inline-formula> non-ergodic computational complexity in terms of floating-point operations for obtaining an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\epsilon$</tex-math></inline-formula>-optimal solution measured by the KKT residual for large-scale DCOPF problems, where <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n$</tex-math></inline-formula> represents the variable dimension, and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N_{L}$</tex-math></inline-formula> denotes the number of branches in the power grid. Extensive numerical tests on large-scale power grids, reaching up to the 9241- bus PEGASE system, demonstrate the scalability and superior efficiency of the developed GPU-based sGS-HPR algorithm compared to state-of-the-art methods. Notably, the proposed method achieves a 6× speedup compared with Gurobi for large-scale instances. Additionally, for ultra-large-scale cases, Gurobi throws an “out-of-memory” error, while the proposed sGS-HPR algorithm maintains its computational scalability and efficiency.

title: Enhancing GNSS RTK Positioning Performance in Challenging Urban Environments with Prior Road Surface Map
authors: Xingxing Li, Jiacheng Qiu, Yuxuan Zhou, Shengyu Li, Chunxi Xia, Shaoquan Feng
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: High-precision global navigation satellite system (GNSS) positioning is critical for autonomous vehicles and intelligent transportation systems. However, it faces significant challenges in urban canyons and signal-obstructed environments, where multipath effects and poor satellite geometry lead to accuracy degradation. In such cases, additional auxiliary information is required. Existing map-aided localization methods either focus on meter-level positioning through road network matching or turning to high-definition (HD) maps with higher maintenance costs. To address this, we propose a lightweight system that constructs road surface maps using only vehicle trajectories and integrates the map information with GNSS real-time kinematic (RTK) to enhance positioning accuracy. Our method leverages geometric constraints by iteratively optimizing the distance from the GNSS antenna to the road surface, applying elevation priors to mitigate vertical uncertainty and improve horizontal accuracy simultaneously, which also enables online calibration of antenna height differences. Experiments were conducted in both controlled test field environments and complex urban road scenario. The results demonstrate notable improvements in positioning accuracy in both horizontal and vertical dimensions. In complex and challenging scenarios, the use of prior road surface constraints led to average improvements of 59.43% in horizontal precision and 89.70% in vertical precision. The proposed road surface map, with its compact data and crowdsourcing compatibility, offers a cost-effective solution for high-precision urban navigation without reliance on expensive HD maps or high-end sensors.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Network-based Indoor Non-Line-of-Sight Optical Wireless Communication
authors: Chengwei Fang, Cuiwei He, Estrid He, Chen Chen, Shuo Li, Sijia Yang, Yinong Wang, Ke Wang
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: Indoor optical wireless communication (OWC) offers high-speed and secure transmission, but is vulnerable to blockage under line-of-sight (LOS) conditions. Non-line-of-sight (NLOS) OWC mitigates this by leveraging diffused optical paths, yet introduces a challenging channel environment with severe multipath dispersion, signal attenuation, device nonlinearity, and inter-symbol interference (ISI)—especially at high data rates. These factors significantly degrade performance and limit the effectiveness of traditional equalizers. This letter proposes a physics-informed neural network (PINN)-based equalizer designed to address the challenges of NLOS indoor OWC. Compared to conventional equalizers, the PINN equalizer improves the bit error rate (BER) by 24.6% to 70.87% under varying data rates and silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) bias currents. Compared to an equalizer based on a vanilla recurrent neural network (RNN), our proposed PINN equalizer reduces the training time by 8.21% to 52.22%. Experimental results confirm the potential of PINN for efficient and robust NLOS indoor OWC.

title: Large Language Models (LLMs) for Network Traffic Prediction: A Trend-Aware Hybrid Framework
authors: Yuzhou Chen, Kwok-Yan Lam, Feng Li
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The explosive growth and increasing complexity of modern 5G/6G networks, driven by Internet-of-Things (IoT), industrial automation, and real‑time multimedia streaming, demand forecasting methods that address non‑stationarity, abrupt shifts, and incomplete observations. Non‑stationarity involves changing statistical properties, abrupt shifts stem from events or outages, and data gaps can impair model accuracy. Traditional statistical models and deep sequence learners partially handle these challenges but often leave systematic residuals, which are structured errors from unmodeled scenarios and overlook high‑level contextual cues such as external events or semantic patterns. To overcome these limitations, we propose a hybrid forecasting framework combining a convolutional neural network–long short-term memory (CNN–LSTM) trend predictor for capturing local fluctuations and long‑range dependencies, an Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) residual corrector to refine forecast errors, and a Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)‑fine‑tuned large language model (LLM) that generates semantic labels of trend direction, anomaly type, and volatility regime to enrich residual learning. Experimental evaluation on real‑world cellular traffic data shows up to 15% reduction in root-mean-square error (RMSE) and 10% reduction in mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) compared to state‑of‑the‑art hybrid baselines, with substantially improved resilience to noise, missing data, and abrupt traffic surges. Our contributions include a parameter‑efficient prompt‑based LoRA fine‑tuning pipeline for adapting LLMs to time‑series forecasting, a context‑aware residual learning architecture fusing numerical and linguistic features, and comprehensive empirical validation demonstrating superior accuracy and robustness in dynamic network environments.

title: Research on Design and Transition Performance Evaluation of High-Precision Large-Size Laminar Flow Nozzle in Wind Tunnel
authors: Xinxin Qi, Qian Yin, Shenghao Yu, Biling Wang, Enhao Li, Weijian Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: This research addresses the design and transition performance evaluation of a high-precision large-size laminar flow nozzle for the FL-63 hypersonic wind tunnel renovation. The nozzle contour was designed using the backward characteristic line method with axial Mach number distribution, replacing traditional wake-assumption approaches to suppress expansion wave interference. A Purdue-type suction slot was integrated to delay boundary layer transition, with slot parameters optimized through CFD simulations at Mach 6 conditions. Computational analysis demonstrated that suction throat height critically influences efficiency: increasing from 1.83 mm to 3.72 mm improved suction efficiency from 15.14-16.78% to 28.05-29.81%. Optimal positioning placed the suction port 20 mm downstream of the nozzle throat, achieving Mach 0.3 inflow without separation. The distance between suction port and suction throat showed minimal efficiency impact (29.70-29.86%) but affected inflow velocity. Slot geometry refinement using a quadratic profile with increased curvature radius eliminated outlet separation zones observed in initial designs. The final configuration achieved 29.8% suction efficiency with high nozzle outlet flow uniformity (mean core Mach number: 6.001, RMS deviation: 0.0042). Transition behavior was evaluated using SST and R-y models. The SST model predicted transition onset upstream of the suction slot at x=-0.08 m, while the R-y model indicated earlier transition near the inlet. Both models confirmed the suction slot effectively delays boundary layer transition, showing ≤5% discrepancy in transition onset prediction x/L ±0.02).

title: A Blockchain-based Architecture For Secure ECG Monitoring Using Constrained IoT Devices
authors: Manel Boujelben, Manel Hentati, Oussama Ghorbel
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Heart disease remains one of the leading causes of death worldwide, posing a significant global health challenge. In recent years, there has been growing interest in designing IoT system architectures and leveraging AI-driven Electrocardiography (ECG) analysis to enhance diagnostic accuracy and efficiency, thereby making high-quality cardiac care more accessible. However, these advancements require secure and efficient diagnostic solutions. In this study, we propose a blockchain-based ECG monitoring system. Blockchain offers a decentralized and transparent approach that enables data provenance, auditability, reliability, and trustworthiness. By integrating Hyperledger Fabric, our approach ensures secure data management, identity verification, and privacy protection. IoT devices connected to ECG sensors placed on the patient’s body are capable of locally monitoring, analyzing ECG signals in real time, and classifying them as normal or abnormal without the need to transfer raw data to an external server. First, we train a hybrid CNN-GRU model using the MIT-BIH dataset. Then, we optimize the model through quantization and deploy it in TensorFlow Lite (TFLite) format for embedded execution. Deployment results show that our model achieves $\mathbf{9 7. 2 \%}$ accuracy with an inference time of approximately 142 ms, while maintaining a compact size, demonstrating its effectiveness for real-time, privacy-preserving healthcare applications.

title: Two-Phase Method for Optimal Mobile Sensor Path Planning To Monitor Coverage Holes in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Maher Rebai, Hani Hamdan, Jinan Charafeddine
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: A Wireless Sensor Network (WSN) may be viewed as a set of sensor devices where each sensor can monitor a specific area and relay detected events to a central data sink for analysis and processing. However, due to factors such as sensor failures or imperfect initial deployment, uncovered areas, known as “coverage holes”, may emerge, leading to gaps in monitoring. To address this issue, mobile sensor nodes can be deployed to dynamically cover these blind regions and restore network coverage. Efficient path planning for these mobile nodes is crucial to ensure maximum coverage while minimizing travel time and energy consumption. In this study, we propose a two-phase optimization-based approach for guiding mobile sensor nodes to efficiently cover uncovered zones in a sensing area. The first phase employs a Binary Integer Linear Programming (BILP) model to determine the optimal number of critical sensing area positions that the mobile sensor must visit to achieve dynamic total area coverage. The second phase identifies the optimal position locations and optimizes the movement trajectory to minimize travel distance. The performance of the two-phase method is evaluated through simulations using various network sizes and node sensing ranges. Comparisons with existing approaches in the literature clearly demonstrate that the proposed approach can achieve superior results in a reasonable time frame.

title: Multimodal Fusion of Behavior Graphs and API Sequences for Ransomware Detection
authors: Dinh Le Thanh Cong, Ho Hoang Diep, Nghi Hoang Khoa, Do Thi Thu Hien, Phan The Duy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference On Cryptography And Information Security (VCRIS)
abstract: Ransomware attacks are increasingly prevalent and pose significant threats, necessitating effective and timely detection methods. In this research, we propose a hybrid neural network architecture specifically designed to leverage the powerful sequential modeling capabilities of xLSTM, effectively capturing complex temporal dependencies in ransomware behaviors. Our proposed model integrates Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) to effectively capture structural relationships in behavioral graphs and Extended Long Short-Term Memory (xLSTM) networks to model temporal patterns within API call sequences. Features extracted from both modalities are fused using a Multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) classifier, capitalizing on their complementary strengths. Experimental results on a comprehensive dataset demonstrate that our proposed model achieves superior detection performance, with an accuracy of up to 99.4% and an F1-score of 99.4%. Moreover, our approach consistently maintains a high true positive rate (TPR) and the lowest false positive rate (FPR) among comparable architectures, validating the effectiveness of integrating structural and sequential behavioral characteristics for enhanced ransomware detection.

title: Analysis and Simulation of a Ducted-Fan Aerial Platform with Aerodynamic Constraints
authors: Tianfu Ai, Feige Pan, Wangwang Zhang, Dequan Zeng, Longjie Zhang, Yibo Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: Ducted-fan aerial platforms are finding growing application in indoor search and tunnel operations areas due to their efficiency, quiet operation, and safety advantages. However, operating in confined spaces induces the proximity effect, which substantially degrades the platform's aerodynamic behavior and control effectiveness, posing significant challenges to stable system operation. This research utilizes a deep neural network (DNN) to develop a dynamic model for the flying platform experiencing aerodynamic interactions with different surroundings. The resulting model demonstrated high accuracy, achieving mean-square errors (MSE) below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mathrm{e}^{-2}$</tex> on both training and test datasets. Building upon this model, a backstepping adaptive controller incorporating the aerodynamic interaction model is introduced. Simulation analyses across various constrained environments were conducted to validate the controller's effectiveness. The simulation results show that compared with the baseline control strategy, the proposed deep learning model combined with the adaptive strategy has smaller tracking errors when the platform maneuvering under constrained environment, proving that its control performance is better. This research is useful for enhancing the flight stability and operational capability of unmanned aerial platforms in different constrained environments.

title: Global and Efficient Local Optimization for Movable Antenna Enabled ISAC
authors: Lebin Chen, Ming-Min Zhao, Min Li, Ming Lei, Minjian Zhao, Rui Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system enabled by movable antennas (MAs), where the base station (BS) transmitter is equipped with MAs to enhance both sensing and communication performance. To characterize the benefits of MA-enabled ISAC systems, we focus on the line-of-sight (LoS) channel scenario and derive the Cramér-Rao bound (CRB) for angle estimation error, which is then minimized by jointly optimizing the antenna position vector (APV) and beamforming design, subject to a pre-defined signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) constraint to ensure the communication performance. Despite the non-convexity of the resulting problem, we develop a boundary traversal breadth-first search (BT-BFS) algorithm to obtain the global optimal solution, along with a lower-complexity boundary traversal depth-first search (BT-DFS) algorithm to find a local optimal solution efficiently. Extensive numerical results are presented to verify the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms, and demonstrate the superiority of the considered MA-enabled ISAC system over conventional ISAC systems with fixed-position antennas (FPAs).

title: AI-Driven Routing in Mega-LEO Constellations: An Enhanced Q-Learning Strategy for Dynamic Topology Adaptation
authors: Gaosai Liu, Xinglong Jiang, Hongming Hu, Siyue Sun, Guang Liang, Haiying Hu, Chunxin Mu
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Mega-Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite constellations are characterized by highly dynamic topologies and stringent performance requirements, posing significant challenges to traditional routing strategies. Reinforcement learning (RL), particularly Q-learning, offers a promising framework for adaptive routing in such environments; however, its slow convergence limits practical deployment. To address this issue, this paper proposes an Enhanced Q-Learning Routing (EQLR) strategy that accelerates convergence through two key mechanisms: (1) pre-initialization of the Q-table leveraging the predictable orbital dynamics of satellites, thereby providing informed initial estimates; and (2) dynamic adjustment of the exploration coefficient based on Q-value variations, enabling a more efficient transition from exploration to exploitation. Simulation results demonstrate that EQLR achieves a $50 \%$ reduction in convergence time compared to conventional Q-learning, facilitating faster stabilization of routing paths under rapidly evolving network conditions. Although the average hop count and end-to-end latency remain comparable to baseline methods, EQLR offers significantly improved responsiveness, making it well-suited for large-scale, latency-sensitive satellite networks.

title: COPS: Collaborative Observability and Privacy-preserving Security in ICS
authors: Wassila Lalouani, Reham Eltomy, Mohamed Baza
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) form the backbone of critical infrastructure, enabling automated monitoring, and control across essential industrial sectors. However, the convergence of legacy ICS with modern networking and computing technologies has significantly broadened their cyberattack surface. Despite this growing vulnerability, many existing anomaly detection techniques depend on centralized architectures that introduce high communication overhead, delayed threat response, and elevated false positive rates, particularly when addressing rare or stealthy attacks. Furthermore, most conventional approaches are optimized for detecting system-level anomalies, often neglecting subtle intrusions that compromise individual ICS components and pose serious security risks. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a collaborative, hierarchical observability and privacy-preserving framework based on distributed Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) architecture. Each sensor’s latent state is captured locally using dedicated LSTM model, and these embeddings are then fused through a dual optimization strategy that supports both sensor-level and system-wide anomaly detection. In contrast to traditional federated learning, our framework enables secure and privacy-preserving exchange of sensor state information across multiple ICS nodes, enhancing the system’s ability to detect coordinated and stealthy attacks. We validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach using the HAI-21.03 dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach successfully identifies both fine-grained sensor anomalies and complex stealthy system-level intrusions, while minimizing communication overhead.

title: Threshold-Based Entity Authentication for PKCS#11: A Cryptographic Protocol Using Shamir’s Secret Sharing
authors: Hoang Van Thuc, Hoang Sy Tuong
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference On Cryptography And Information Security (VCRIS)
abstract: PKCS#11 is a widely adopted Application Programming Interface (API) standard designed to facilitate interactions between applications and cryptographic devices such as smart cards, USB tokens, and Hardware Security Modules (HSMs). It defines entity authentication mechanisms—covering both Security Officers (SO) and regular users—based primarily on static Personal Identification Numbers (PINs). However, static PIN-based authentication exhibits significant security limitations in high-assurance environments.This paper introduces an enhanced authentication mechanism for the SO role in the PKCS#11 framework, addressing the vulnerabilities of default static credentials. The proposed solution employs Shamir’s threshold secret sharing scheme, wherein the authentication secret is divided into n shares, requiring collaboration from at least k administrators to reconstruct the secret (k ≤ n). This approach eliminates single points of failure and mitigates the risk of privilege misuse.The mechanism is integrated with modern cryptographic primitives, including PBKDF2 and AES-256-CBC, to strengthen resilience against brute-force and impersonation attacks. Experimental evaluation within a PKCS#11-compliant environment demonstrates that total authentication latency remains below 200 ms, with storage overhead under 1 KB—fully compatible with commercial HSM deployment requirements. These findings confirm the practicality of the solution for real-world application in critical infrastructure, aligning with the PKCS#11 (OASIS, 2024) recommendations for advanced access control enhancement.

title: Three-Dimensional Path Planning for UAVs Based on Lemur Multi-Objective Optimization and the Optimal Velocity Obstacle Method
authors: Chao Zhang, Qian Tang, Jingyu Wang, Xing Fang, Jingrui Zhang, Junqing Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: As an emerging strategic industry, the low-altitude economy is growing rapidly but faces many challenges, among which UAV path planning is a key issue. This paper proposes a three-dimensional UAV path planning method based on Multi-Objective Lemurs Optimizer (MOLO) and Optimal Reciprocal Collision Avoidance (ORCA) algorithm, in response to the safety and path planning requirements of UAVs in the low-altitude economy. Firstly, the objective functions, including path length, collision detection, flight height, and smoothness, are constructed, and the lemur optimizer is extended by introducing the Pareto optimal solution theory to form a multi-objective optimization framework. Secondly, ORCA algorithm is combined to enhance the dynamic adaptability of path planning, enabling real-time avoidance of dynamic obstacles through speed adjustment strategies. Simulation experiments show that the MOLO algorithm achieves leading multi-objective path planning performance on multiple maps compared with algorithms like MOPSO and MOGWO, and demonstrates excellent obstacle avoidance capabilities in dynamic scenarios when combined with ORCA. This provides an efficient path planning solution for the UAVs safe flight in the development of the low-altitude economy.

title: Districts-to-Zone-to-City To Building-to-Neighborhood-to-Cities: Big Data Driven Architecture Enabling a Five-Category Centric Framework for Smart, Sustainable, Scalable and Reliable IoT City Services
authors: Amir Sinaeepourfard, Shehenaz Shaik, Niusha Mesgaribarzi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Urbanization and digital transformation are pushing cities to deploy advanced Internet of Things (IoT) and Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructures to improve sustainability and quality of life. By engaging residents, industries, and municipalities, smart cities use data-driven strategies to navigate complex challenges. To overcome issues like energy optimization, climate change, and population growth, cities must implement scalable and intelligent ICT architectures that efficiently manage data. Expanding on the first author’s novel contributions in previous studies, this paper introduces a holistic Five-Category Centric framework to address the complexities of decentralized, distributed, and hybrid ICT architectures. This framework integrates five dimensions: “business,” “user,” “technology,” “sustainability,” and “partner & ecosystem.” The key contribution is the selection and mapping of two previously proposed ICT architectures-Fog-to-Cloud Data Management (F2C-DM), applied to District-to-Zone-toCity Data Management, and Distributed-to-Centralized Software Management (D2C-SM), applied to Building-to-Neighborhoods-to-Cities Data Management-onto the new Five-Category Centric framework. This alignment is demonstrated, showcasing how the framework seamlessly integrates edge-level fog processing with centralized cloud management, optionally utilizing both private and public multi-cloudlet and cloud solutions, while also enabling both independent and orchestrated hierarchical multi-tier management across edge-to-cloud solutions. This approach ensures Smart, Sustainable, Scalable, and Reliable IoT service management for smart cities. The framework supports both end-to-end urban and citizen demands, as well as ICT/IoT applications for operations, resource management, and service delivery. It covers services from building and neighborhood up to district, zone, and city scales, mapping edge, fog, cloudlet, and cloud infrastructures to improve orchestration efficiency and interoperability.

title: Monitoring the Seasonal Behavior and Morphological Changes of the Hunga Iceberg Using Sentinel-1 SAR data
authors: Mozhgan Zahriban Hesari, Andrea Buono, Giuseppe Aulicino, Maurizio Migliaccio
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: This study presents the temporal monitoring and structural assessment of the Hunga iceberg using dual-polarized Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data acquired from January 2022 to April 2023. A time series analysis was conducted using one SAR acquisition per month to observe iceberg drift, rotation and deformation under varying environmental conditions in Terra Nova Bay, Antarctica. The seasonal impact on iceberg motion was evident: during Antarctic summer (Octo-ber-March), the iceberg drifted freely in open water, while in winter (April-September), dense sea ice limited iceberg drifting significantly. A significant fragmentation event was detected in April 2023, which was validated by comparing the areas of fractured parts with the original iceberg footprint. These findings demonstrate the capability of dual-polarized SAR data in monitoring iceberg dynamics and detecting structural changes over time.

title: Characterization of Deletion/Substitution Channel Capacity for Small Deletion and Substitution Probabilities
authors: Mohammad Kazemi, Tolga M. Duman
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We consider binary input deletion/substitution channels, which model certain types of synchronization errors encountered in practice. Specifically, we focus on the regime of small deletion and substitution probabilities, and by extending an approach developed for the deletion-only channel, we obtain an asymptotic characterization of the channel capacity for independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) deletion/substitution channels. To do so, given a target probability of successful decoding, we first develop an upper bound on the codebook size for arbitrary but fixed numbers of deletions and substitutions, and then extend the result to the case of random deletions and substitutions to obtain a bound on the channel capacity. Our final result is: The i.i.d. deletion/substitution channel capacity is approximately 1 − H(p<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf>) − H(p<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf>), for p<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf>, p<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf> ≈ 0, where p<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> and p<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf> are the deletion and substitution probabilities, respectively.

title: Cross-Scale Damage Mechanism Analysis of T800 Carbon Fiber Composites Under Hygrothermal Aging
authors: Xiaohan Sun, Wei Huang, Feng Guo, Jinshen Xu, Xiong Chen, Hongwei Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: T800 carbon fiber composite material has excellent comprehensive performance and is widely used in national defense, military industry, aerospace and other fields. The aging environment has a significant impact on its performance. In this study, hygrothermal aging tests were conducted on T800 carbon fiber composites. The micromechanical parameters of the composites were characterized and compared with their macro-mechanical properties. The results indicate that during hygrothermal aging, the resin matrix gradually detaches from the fiber surface, accompanied by fiber filament pull-out and fracture, ultimately leading to material failure and a decline in mechanical performance. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses reveal significant molecular-level structural damage in the T800 carbon fiber composites. Experimental data demonstrate that chemical reactions occur among elemental groups in the material as aging progresses: The proportion of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C=C$</tex> group decreased, while the proportion of the C-C group increased significantly. Meanwhile, the content of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{O}$</tex> group decreased, and the content of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{O}$</tex> group showed an increasing trend. These changes in elemental composition suggest that oxidative crosslinking or oxidative decomposition may occur during the aging process. The cross-scale correlation between microscopic characterization parameters and macroscopic mechanical properties indicates that the degradation trend of the macroscopic mechanical properties of T800 carbon fiber composites has a certain correlation with the relative transmittance of microscopic hydroxyl molecules and the content of elemental groups.

title: Identity management for frameworks managing northbound APIs of future networks
authors: Emma O’Brien, Breno Da Costa Paulo, Angel Martin, Muhammad Shuaib Siddiqui, Sergio Giménez-Antón
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Future networks will deliver unprecedented performance, versatility, and efficiency, driven by advancements in automated monitoring and control. As networks evolve into interconnected platforms capable of enabling advanced features, allocating assets, and configuring them via northbound Application Programming Interfaces (APIs), dynamic control over multiple actors and stakeholders becomes essential. At this point, identity management plays a crucial role in overseeing onboarding, administering access, and registering activity to log and account for all operations. This paper compares the Open Common API Framework (CAPIF), based on the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) standard, with a novel distributed identity-based approach using Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT). To assess the viability of these solutions, various tests are conducted to evaluate the frameworks’ latency and processing workloads.

title: Research on Low Altitude Wind Field Characteristics in Urban Residential Areas Based on Numerical Simulation
authors: Ao Xu, Bao Chen, Jingfei Liu, Guang Yang, Anran Ju, Siyu Hou
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: In response to flight safety demands under the rapid development of the low-altitude economy, this study systematically investigates the three-dimensional wind field characteristics of a typical high-density residential area using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) numerical simulation. Targeting the complex wind environments formed by urban canopy effects-including local circulations, building-induced turbulence, and other wind field phenomena-the research focuses on the influence mechanisms of building clusters on macro-scale wind field structures, micro-scale turbulence distributions and special wind field morphologies in low-altitude flight zones under varying wind speeds and dominant wind directions. By implementing the Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) equations and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k-\varepsilon$</tex> turbulence model, the study reveals the following key findings: 1.Acceleration effects: windward buildings generate acceleration zones with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30 \%-40 \%$</tex> speed amplification on both sides. 2.Wake characteristics: downwind areas exhibit extended low-speed wake regions spanning 4-6 times the building height, where wind speeds decay to below 40 % of the background flow. 3.Special wind field phenomena: about canyon winds, when building spacing is not more than 12 m, the maximum speed increase in canyon winds reaches 30 %; about roof vortices, velocity gradients exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> form in vortex separation zones due to roof flow detachments; about multi-scale vortex coupling, internal courtyards exhibit coupled multi-scale vortices, directly impacting aircraft stability. This study quantitatively reveals the evolution law of the vertical wind field structure (ground flow layer, building interference layer, roof turbulence layer) in low airspace of urban residential areas, and suggests establishing a typical wind field standard model for low altitude environments to assist risk prediction.

title: Dynamical Linear Reward Systems under Competitive Horizon Criteria
authors: Mor Nahum, Oron Sabag, Michael Langberg
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We consider reward systems defined as iterative decision-making processes, where a player selects an action from the unit interval, and the environment responds by choosing a reward function from a known set of functions. The goal of the player is to accumulate rewards that exceed a given threshold in minimal time, and the performance is measured via regret with respect to an optimal player who knows the entire sequence of reward functions in advance. The central challenge lies in the dynamical nature of the reward system: each time step may involve a different reward function, requiring the player’s policy to adapt over time and making the regret an infinite-letter optimization problem. Our main result is an explicit expression for the optimal regret in the case of two linear reward functions that have opposing slopes. Moreover, we show that the optimal regret is achieved by a piecewise-constant action sequence, where both the transition times and action values exhibit special structural properties. These properties seem fundamental and may extend to classes of nonlinear reward functions. Finally, we highlight the implications of our solution in the context of communication, particularly, in characterizing the capacity of arbitrarily varying channels (AVCs) under competitive performance criteria.

title: Adaptive Bionic Cable-Driven Manipulator for Space Grasping Tasks
authors: Yanshun Sun, Xinyu Yu, Hao An, QianQian Wu, Linzhi Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: To overcome the excessive weight/volume, poor shock resistance and low load-to-weight ratio problems in traditional space manipulators, this study designs a prototype of adaptive bionic cable-driven manipulator (CDM). This CDM is designed with gradient-configured pulley diameters (proximal increasing/distal decreasing) and Kevlar fiber figure-8 winding. The integrated structure of CDM achieves compactness and flexibility while reducing weight-to-volume, significantly. The modular knuckle design results in finger/knuckle quantity expansion and gripping surface envelope adjustment based on operational requirements. Driving torque analysis demonstrates that a single motor can synchronously drive multiple knuckles through pulley assemblies. By adding a fiber tension modulation and pulley diameter gradient, the optimal torque allocation is achieved, enabling sequential knuckle bending for adaptive grasping of variously shaped objects. In addition, a structural lightweight design is performed through static simulations with full considerations on Kevlar fiber tensile strength and carbon fiber knuckle stiffness. By implementing kinematic modeling on this manipulator, both forward and inverse equations are derived and operational space mappings are obtained. This bionic manipulator is further integrated with an intelligent space flying robot for autonomous space grasping tasks, and ground experiments show both effectiveness and adaptability of our designed bionic manipulator.

title: Efficient Machine Unlearning by Model Splitting and Core Sample Selection
authors: Maximilian Egger, Rawad Bitar, Rüdiger Urbanke
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: Machine unlearning is essential for meeting legal obligations such as the right to be forgotten, which requires the removal of specific data from machine learning models upon request. While several approaches to unlearning have been proposed, existing solutions often struggle with efficiency and, more critically, with the verification of unlearning—particularly in the case of weak unlearning guarantees, where verification remains an open challenge. We introduce a generalized variant of the standard unlearning metric that enables more efficient and precise unlearning strategies. We also present an unlearning-aware training procedure that, in many cases, allows for exact unlearning. We term our approach MaxRR. When exact unlearning is not feasible, MaxRR still supports efficient unlearning with properties closely matching those achieved through full retraining.

title: Design of MEMS Flow Sensors and Their Application Progress in the Aerospace Field
authors: Yunzhi Huang, Lei Zhou, Sirui Ling, Jing Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: The aerospace industry has a growing demand for high-precision sensing of fluid flow velocity and direction, imposing stringent requirements on sensor performance, reliability, and environmental adaptability. Beyond measuring key flow parameters-such as velocity, direction, and temperature-flow sensors must also contend with extreme operational conditions, including high pressure, cryogenic temperatures, and turbulent flows, presenting significant design challenges. This review examines recent advances in microelectromechanical systems (MEMS)-based flow sensor design and their applications in aerospace. While piezoresistive, piezoelectric, and thermal sensing mechanisms remain fundamental, aerospace-specific demands have driven notable innovations in materials, structural optimization, and fabrication techniques. Furthermore, this paper discusses critical challenges and future prospects for MEMS flow sensors in aerospace, such as robustness in harsh environments, miniaturization for lightweight integration, and smart monitoring capabilities.

title: A Framework-Driven Mapping of ADS-B Vulnerabilities to NIST RMF and AI RMF
authors: Antione Searcy, Thabet Kacem
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: The increase in worldwide flight traffic and the growing number of aerial vehicles necessitate the incorporation of innovative technologies into aviation regulatory practices. The Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast (ADS-B) system complies with the International Civil Aviation Organization’s recent flight safety regulations and is now widely adopted by most airlines. Nevertheless, ADS-B features some serious vulnerabilities due its open nature which may results in several attacks such as spoofing endangering flight operations. In addition, ADS-B governance requirements vary significantly per regions while AI-based methods lack formal oversight and alignment with AI governance. In this paper, we bridge this gap by providing a mapping of ADS-B vulnerabilities, attacks and AI-based solutions with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Risk Management Framework (RMF), and the NIST AI RMF. We also highlight the ADS-B mandates in case studies focusing on USA, Europe, Canada, China and Australia. Our findings highlights the gap in applying cybersecurity and AI risk management frameworks in aviation. This paper would serve as a reference for key stakeholders in aviation aiming to conduct further research in this field and establish a foundational layered governance framework that addresses all the highlighted gaps in this work.

title: NeVo: Advancing Volumetric Video Streaming with Neural Content Representation
authors: Nan Wu, Bo Chen, Ruizhi Cheng, Klara Nahrstedt, Bo Han
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Offering high-quality immersive content is the ultimate goal of volumetric video streaming. Although point clouds and meshes are dominant volumetric representations, their limitations in depicting photo-realistic content often undermine user experience. The recent advent of neural radiance fields (NeRF) offers a promising alternative content representation with superior photo-realism. However, streaming NeRF-based volumetric videos over wireless networks to mobile headsets faces significant challenges, including substantial bandwidth usage because of the large frame size, degraded visual quality due to even a low packet loss rate, and content artifacts caused by performance optimizations (e.g., remote rendering at the network edge). To address these challenges, in this paper, we introduce NeVo, a next-generation volumetric video streaming system for efficient delivery of neural content such as NeRF. NeVo incorporates the following innovations into a holistic system: (1) a novel method to model visibility of implicitly encoded neural content, thereby avoiding non-essential transmission to drastically reduce network data usage, (2) a lightweight, learning-based model for real-time content reconstruction after packet loss with carefully chosen data, and (3) judicious identification and selective delivery of intermediate data in edge-based NeRF rendering to effectively mitigate artifacts. Our extensive experiments indicate that compared with the state-of-the-art, NeVo saves up to 68.3% of bandwidth usage, maintains high visual quality despite packet loss, and enhances user experience by reducing artifacts.

title: Poster: mmWave CSI-based Sensing: a Feasibility Study
authors: Joana Angjo, Elena Tonini, Falko Dressler, Renato Lo Cigno
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Channel state information (CSI) is widely used for joint communication and sensing in sub-6 GHz wireless networks, but its application at mmWave frequencies remains under-explored. This work applies a quantized amplitude-based CSI similarity metric to data from a 28 GHz indoor testbed, showing the feasibility of CSI-based ambient sensing in next-generation wireless networks.

title: ESPIRO: Natural Pulmonary Function Monitoring via Earphone-Acquired Speech
authors: Yetong Cao, Dong Ma, Wentao Xie, Qian Zhang, Jun Luo
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: As a crucial tool for assessing health, spirometry provides valuable insights into pulmonary functions. Recent advancements have enabled more convenient measurements by shifting spirometry solutions from cumbersome clinical devices to portable devices. However, the forced maneuvers and burdensome procedures, which necessitate repeated maximal forced breathing, often lead to dizziness and discomfort, rendering them unsuitable for vulnerable populations. In this paper, we present ESPIRO (Earphone-enabled Speech sPIROmetry) system to furnish user-friendly pulmonary function monitoring for diverse populations. Basically, ESPIRO records normal speech using microphone-embedded earphones and characterizes pulmonary function-related glottal flow during speech production. ESPIRO advances existing spirometry solutions in i) leveraging phonetics to associate pulmonary function with glottal flow in normal speech, thereby eliminating the need for forced breathing; ii) identifying effective speech features according to physiological basis, ensuring reliable spirometry measurements; and iii) effectively addressing ambient noise, making it suitable for various real-world settings. Extensive experiments with 38 subjects on 18 commodity earphones confirm that ESPIRO accurately estimates pulmonary function indices in practice.

title: Sensing accuracy enhancement of phase-sensitive optical frequency domain reflectometry using hybrid Hampel-Median filter
authors: Yiheng Cheng, Qinlin Zeng, Fei Liu, Fei Cui, Zhi Wang, Dan Li, Benzhang Wang, Xian Zhou
publish: IEEE Photonics Journal
abstract: We propose a novel filter scheme to enhance the sensing accuracy of phase-sensitive optical frequency domain reflectometer (Φ-OFDR) while maintaining high spatial resolution via cascading Hampel filter and median filter. The working principle is theoretically analyzed and optimal filtering parameters are analyzed with the practical experimental configuration. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a temperature accuracy of 0.49°C, indicating a 28 dB enhancement compared with the raw data while maintaining 4.6 mm spatial resolution. Compared to other conventional filtering methods applied in Φ-OFDR, the proposed hybrid Hampel-Median filter yields about 2∼4 times improvement in sensing accuracy and increases SNR by more than 5 dB with consistent spatial resolution condition. On the other hand, the proposed filtering method enhances the spatial resolution about 2∼6 times with the same sensing accuracy. The experimental results reveal that the novel filtering approach enables high sensing accuracy and spatial resolution for the distributed temperature or strain sensing scenarios of Φ-OFDR, without any hardware modifications.

title: Dual-Input Single-Output Voltage Multiplier-Based High Step-Up Converter for Renewable Energy Integration in DC Microgrids
authors: Seyed Majid Hashemzadeh, Binxin Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: This paper proposes a new non-isolated high step-up DC-DC converter topology based on voltage multiplier networks, designed for renewable energy-based DC microgrids. The proposed converter features dual input ports, enabling power delivery to the output from two distinct power sources with different voltage levels, such as photovoltaic panels and fuel cells. Key advantages include a simple structure, reduced voltage stress across power switches, high voltage gain, high power efficiency, and common ground between input and output ports. Additionally, the topology exhibits low input current ripple, which is critical for maximizing the lifespan and performance of renewable energy sources. The paper presents a detailed analysis of the operational modes, steady-state performance, and design procedure, along with a comprehensive design procedure and comparative study. Finally, a 200 W/ 200 V prototype is built, and experimental results are presented to confirm the effectiveness of the proposed topology.

title: LRCDA: A Lightweight and Reusable Cross-Domain Authentication Scheme for Industrial IoT Based on Distributed Architecture
authors: Yi Wu, Tao Feng, Chunyan Liu, Chunhua Su
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the continuous expansion of industrial internet of things (IIoT) applications, secure cross-domain authentication has emerged as a critical technical challenge. Traditional authentication schemes based on trusted third parties suffer from single point of failure risks, while blockchain-based decentralized approaches incur excessive computational overhead. Both methods share a common deficiency: authentication nodes must repeatedly execute authentication procedures at each target domain’s gateway when performing cross-domain authentication. This repetitive mechanism significantly increases resource consumption and limits the system’s ability to satisfy strict real-time requirements. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a lightweight and reusable cross-domain authentication scheme (LRCDA) based on distributed architecture. First, the proposed scheme, based on the Chinese Remainder Theorem, enables edge nodes to autonomously establish system keys and independently verify identities, completely eliminating dependence on centralized third parties and mitigating single point of failure risks. Furthermore, the scheme introduces a cross-domain reusable signature mechanism, allowing signature to be securely reused across multiple security domains during its validity period, thereby reducing the frequency of signature generation and minimizing authentication latency. Moreover, through efficient task allocation, computationally intensive operations are offloaded to edge nodes, thereby reducing the computational burden on terminal devices. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that the LRCDA scheme meets the security and privacy requirements for cross-domain authentication in industrial IoT environments, encompassing anonymity, signature unforgeability, and resistance to man-in-the-middle attacks. Experimental evaluations reveal that LRCDA scheme reduces authentication latency by 77.4% compared to traditional schemes and by 88.2% compared to existing distributed approaches, demonstrating significant efficiency gains for resource-constrained industrial IoT deployments.

title: FungAI - A Clinically-Oriented Two-Stage Artificial Intelligence Framework for Microscopic Fungal Species Identification
authors: Millie Ming Rong Goh, Lin Zou, Yen Ee Tan, Mei Gie Tan, Han Leong Goh, Benny Kai Loong Yip, Andy Wee An Ta, Tse Hsien Koh
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Fungal infections represent a growing global health threat, especially for individuals with compromised immune systems. Accurate and timely species-level identification is essential for effective treatment but is often hindered by the labor-intensive and expertise-dependent nature of manual microscopic examination. This study presents FungAI, a two-stage deep learning pipeline for the automated classification of 20 clinically relevant fungal species from microscopic images. The first stage leverages deep learning models, including CNNs, Vision Transformers (ViTs), and Mamba-based architectures, to establish a robust classification backbone. While these models achieved high accuracy for filamentous fungi, they exhibited limitations in differentiating morphologically similar yeast species. To address this, a second-stage classifier was introduced and trained on handcrafted morphological features, enabling fine-grained discrimination among yeast classes. This addition led to significant performance gains, particularly when tested on the external test set, with accuracy improvements of up to approximately 10 percentage points. The best-performing model - a FungAI Two-Stage NextViT–MambaVision ensemble - achieved 92% accuracy across both holdout and external test sets. The proposed framework demonstrates strong potential for clinical deployment, reducing diagnostic turnaround time from up to 28 days to just 2 days. These results underscore the value of combining diverse architectural approaches with domain-specific morphological insights, setting a new benchmark for AI-driven medical mycology.

title: Enhanced Control of Single-Stage PV-STATCOM Using Hybrid MPPT and Adaptive AHLMS for Power Quality Improvement
authors: Nagwa F. Ibrahim, I. M. Elzein, Mohamed Metwally Mahmoud, Ali M. El-Rifaie, Hany S. Hussein, Mohammed A. Elsayed Eid
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper introduces an enhanced control strategy for a single-stage PV-STATCOM integrated with a power system. The system is designed to efficiently deliver solar energy to both the load and the grid while significantly improving power quality (PQ). It employs a Hybrid pelican and perturb and observe (HPPO) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) based Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm to consistently extract peak power from the PV array. AHLMS, with its adaptive hysteresis load management system, generates reference signals for both active and reactive grid currents for controlling the switching operation of a voltage source converter. In addition, this intelligent procedure tunes the control parameters in real-time to reduce tracking errors and adapts dynamically to environmental variations, including solar irradiance, load imbalances, and nonlinearities. The proposed PV-STATCOM is considered PQ-enhanced because it provides reactive power compensation, suppresses harmonic distortion (HD), stabilizes system voltages, and improves the power factor (PF). The output current remains sinusoidal and fits well with minimal HD while complying with IEEE-519 standards. Mathematical simulation in MATLAB/Simulink were applied, along with comparisons to the most recent methodologies, ensures that this system outperforms others under varying sunlight, nonlinear, and unbalanced loading conditions.

title: Detection Scheme of Multiple Submodule Open-Circuit Faults for Rectifier MMCs in HVDC System: A Simulation-Based Investigation
authors: Zhi Geng, Yong Yang, Yang Xiao, Wenqiang Xie, Guangyang Zhou, Kai Ni
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Rectifier mode, measurement dependence and high-voltage application of modular multilevel converter (MMC) pose serious challenges to submodule (SM) open-circuit fault detection. In this paper, a fault detection scheme for multiple SM failures is proposed. To handle the influence of rectifier mode, this detection is based on the fault feature of SM output voltage. Furthermore, the fault feature is presented by calculating the deviation between actual and expected common voltages via circulating current loop model, which lowers the dependence on the measurement devices. Then, the component in the deviation is analyzed in detail and the filter and delay subtraction are taken. By that, model errors can be cleared, which raises both the detection precision and rapidity. Based on the above, the distinguishing method is also proposed for the different fault cases to handle the diverse and complex failure combinations in high-voltage MMCs. Moreover, the comparisons indicate that the proposed detection can yield stronger detection performance, simpler implementation requirements, ampler fault messages and lower computation burden. The effectiveness of the proposed fault detection scheme is verified by simulation results in Matlab/Simulink.

title: IrregFusion: A Generalized Framework for Hyperspectral Image Fusion across Diverse Spectral Data
authors: Jiangtao Nie, Wei Wei, Lei Zhang, Chen Ding, Yanning Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Fusing a low-resolution (LR) hyperspectral image (HSI) with a high-resolution (HR) multispectral image (MSI) has emerged as a promising strategy for reconstructing high-quality HSIs that combine rich spectral and fine spatial information. However, most existing HSI fusion methods operate under the restrictive assumption that the LR HSI and HR MSI are spatially aligned and fully consistent on the field-of-view (FoV), which significantly limits their applicability in real-world scenarios when such alignment is unavailable. To overcome these limitations, we propose IrregFusion, a generalized HSI fusion framework capable of handling both FoV-consistent and inconsistent fusion scenarios. Specifically, IrregFusion incorporates a Transformer-based reconstruction module that captures both intra- and inter-modal correlations between the diverse spectra data and the MSI, enhancing the model’s ability to perceive and reconstruct non-local spectral–spatial structures. To further address the challenges posed by FoV inconsistencies, we introduce a spectral propagation strategy that diffuses observed spectral information into adjacent spectral-blank regions, thereby easing the reconstruction of missing spectral content. Additionally, a self-supervised adaptation mechanism is integrated into the framework, enabling robust spectral–spatial representation learning and enhancing generalization across diverse and challenging conditions. Extensive experiments conducted on benchmark datasets demonstrate that IrregFusion effectively addresses the challenges of diverse spectral data fusion and consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both reconstruction accuracy and visual fidelity. The source code will be released in https://github.com/JiangtaoNie/IrregFusion.git.

title: LiDAR Inertial Odometry for Vehicle Positioning Based on Multimodal Attention Fusion Network
authors: Xuezhen Liu, Yongyi Chen, Dan Zhang, Peng Sun, Yanbiao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Multi-sensor information fusion is one of the effective methods to improve the accuracy of odometry estimation, which can help reduce the cumulative error. In recent years, the deep learning method has been extensively applied in this field due to its ability to automatically extract the features related to the vehicle's motion from sensor data. However, how to effectively fuse IMU data and LiDAR data using supervised learning remains a challenge. In this paper, a LiDAR inertial odometry (LIO) estimation method based on multimodal attention fusion network (MAFNet) is proposed for vehicle positioning. In the MAFNet, two feature extraction modules, i.e., spatio-temporal feature extraction module (STFE) and multi-motion feature extraction module (MMFE) are constructed. The motion features of the vehicle are indirectly extracted by STFE through the collection of change information in point clouds at different moments. The complex correlations and time dependencies of rotations and translations in different directions are innovatively learned by the MMFE, improving the model's understanding of the complex pose changes of the vehicle. Feature association guided learning mechanism (FAGLM) is then designed to guide the fusion of heterogeneous modal features by learning the correlation among multimodal features and reducing the redundant information in the features. Finally, the proposed MAFNet is applied to the Kitti odometry dataset and ablation experiments are designed to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method. The experimental results show that MAFNet outperforms the existing methods and achieves excellent estimation performance.

title: Single-Ended 3T Sense Amplifiers for Amorphous Oxide Semiconductor 2T0C DRAM
authors: Seong-Jun Byun, Jeong-Min Lee, Joon-Kyu Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Conventional dynamic random access memory (DRAM) utilizes differential sense amplifiers (SAs) to resolve small voltage differences between bitline (BL) and BL-bar (BLB), and necessitates refresh operation, BL/BLB equalization, and offset-cancellation. However, amorphous-oxide-semiconductor (AOS) two-transistor zero-capacitor (2T0C) DRAM separates the read and write paths and utilizes low <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</small>-current of AOS devices, achieving a long retention time and eliminating the need for differential sensing. This study proposes single-ended three-transistor (3T) SAs in voltage-mode and current-mode for AOS 2T0C DRAM, achieving refresh-, equalization-, and offset cancellation-free operation with high area efficiency and integration density. After fabricating the AOS 2T0C DRAM, SPICE simulations are performed using 45 nm technology, confirming a low maximum sensing delay and read energy. The voltage-mode and current-mode SAs achieve average sensing delays of 1.26 and 1.47 ns, respectively. They demonstrate <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$9\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> reduction in power-delay product (PDP) with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> fewer transistors compared to state-of-the-art SA designs.
