title: FedSSL-NTC: A Robust Federated Self-Supervised Learning Framework for Network Traffic Classification Under Privacy Constraints
authors: Ehsan Eslami, Walaa Hamouda
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Network traffic classification (NTC) plays an essential role in managing, securing, and optimizing networks. Supervised learning methods face challenges such as label scarcity. Given that network traffic contains sensitive data and is distributed across multiple nodes, privacy-aware and scalable approaches are necessary for real-world deployment. In this paper, we introduce FedSSL-NTC, a privacy-enhancing federated framework that integrates self-supervised learning (SSL) and a traffic-adapted confident learning (CL) approach. In FedSSL-NTC, clients locally pretrain SSL models (Autoencoders or Tabular Contrastive Learning) and generate pseudo-labels. CL is then applied on the client side to reduce pseudo-label noise before federated classifier training. Robustness to non-independently and non-identically distributed (non-IID) data and class imbalance is achieved via FedProx, class-weighted loss, and a sample-size weighted FedAvg aggregation method. This framework uses Secure Aggregation to protect individual updates. On a self-generated + ISCX VPN-nonVPN dataset and the UCDavis–QUIC dataset, FedSSL-NTC achieves 95.88% and 98.24% accuracy (vs. centralized 96.29% and 98.76%), while reducing training time by approximately 4–5× through parallel client updates. The method outperforms recent federated/self-supervised baselines on the same evaluation protocol (e.g., 6% improvement compared to FS-GAN). Therefore, FedSSL-NTC offers a practical path to high-accuracy NTC under privacy constraints, non-IID distributions, and label scarcity.

title: Equivalent Regulation Mechanism of Electron Density Distribution in Vacuum Arcs by Transverse Magnetic Fields and Contact Gaps
authors: Chongyang Huang, Jishi Yan, Si Fu, Hanwen Du, Zhengbo Li, Feiran Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Taking single-break DC vacuum circuit breakers as the research object, an experimental platform for collecting characteristic information of DC vacuum arcs was established. High-speed cameras were used to capture images of the zero-zone process of vacuum arcs under transverse magnetic fields, flat contacts, and different commutation gaps. Spectrometers were employed to collect characteristic spectral lines at Cu I 521.8 nm, from which electron temperature and electron density were calculated and analyzed. The study found that under the same operating condition with a commutation gap of 6 mm, the swastika-shaped transverse magnetic field (TMF) contacts can effectively regulate the spatial distribution of arc plasma. Compared with the case without magnetic field, the radial distribution uniformity of electron density is significantly improved, and the ratio of electron density between the center and the edge on the cathode contact surface decreases from 7:1 to 1.6:1. Increasing the contact gap can improve the spatial distribution uniformity of electron density. The transverse magnetic field gap (6 mm) and increasing the contact gap (10 mm) under no magnetic field conditions have equivalent regulatory effects on the radial/axial distribution of electron density. Both increasing the gap and enhancing the magnetic field improve the uniformity of plasma spatial distribution and reduce the difference in electron density between the center and edge of the contact surface. The transverse magnetic field can equivalently replace increasing the gap to achieve stable arc control.

title: An Interface Modeling Method for Avionics Software Based on Open System Architecture
authors: Suo Zhao, Chenliang Xin, Yiming Shan
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: In response to exponential growth in software complexity, the industry has been actively exploring open system architecture and model-based development approaches separately with demonstrable success. This paper introduces model-based approach into the open avionics software architectures, proposing a model based open avionics software interface modeling method. By extending the SysML modeling language, this paper proposes a modeling framework for software interface definition within hierarchical open architectures compliant with the Future Airborne Capability Environment open architecture. Also, an engineering practice optimized modeling process is proposed to enable consistent implementation of software interface modeling activities. Leveraging the widely adopted industry-standard modeling languages, the proposed approach mitigates practitioner's learning costs and streamlines software integration and reuse under open architecture through model reusability, ultimately enhancing software interface design efficiency. Furtherly, practical engineering application have demonstrated that the proposed method improves the interface definition efficiency and reduce interface definition errors with standardized and reusable data models.

title: Enhancing Cyber-Physical Systems Security with Digital Twins, Blockchain, and Anomaly Detection
authors: Mostafa Shehata, Yasmine N. M. Saleh, Ayman Abdel-Hamid
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) are critical infrastructural components for industrial processes, such as those employed in Oil and Gas plants. CPS security is of crucial consideration. This paper investigates how to enhance the security of CPS of Industrial Control Systems (ICS), specifically addressing the challenge of anomaly detection. To that end, a framework integrating Digital Twin technology, Blockchain, and an anomaly detection technique is proposed. Through simulation using a Digital Twin Docker based framework, and Hyperledger Fabric Blockchain, the framework is evaluated by analyzing operation logs generated during various cyberattacks. Key findings show that anomaly detection plays a pivotal role in identifying cyber threats, while Blockchain ensures secure data storage and authentication. The results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly improves CPS security, presenting a promising solution for protecting critical industrial systems.

title: Enhancing Vector-Based Feature Representation for Malicious Network Traffic Detection
authors: Yassine Belkhouche, Seojin Park
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Many researchers have employed convolutional neural networks(CNNs) for malicious network traffic detection. CNNs use the convolution operation to extract features from a grid-like input. The convolution operation finds and extracts discriminating features if there are dependencies between the neighboring grid cells. These dependencies may not exist in the extracted network traffic features. This paper establishes a method to transform and expand the original network traffic extracted features into an image-based representation. We proposed a technique to expand and enhance the initial vector-based network traffic features into a 2 D image representation using multiple shift-rotate operations. We tested the proposed method using two widely used malicious network traffic detection datasets. We obtained an average accuracy higher than $95 \%$.

title: An Information Geometric Approach to Local Information Privacy with Applications to Max-lift and Local Differential Privacy
authors: Amirreza Zamani, Parastoo Sadeghi, Mikael Skoglund
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We study an information-theoretic privacy mechanism design, where an agent observes useful data Y and wants to reveal the information to a user. Since the useful data is correlated with the private data X, the agent uses a privacy mechanism to produce disclosed data U that can be released. We assume that the agent observes Y and has no direct access to X, i.e., the private data is hidden. We study the privacy mechanism design that maximizes the revealed information about Y while satisfying a bounded Local Information Privacy (LIP) criterion. When the leakage is sufficiently small, concepts from information geometry allow us to locally approximate the mutual information. By utilizing this approximation the main privacy-utility trade-off problem can be rewritten as a quadratic optimization problem that has closed-form solution under some constraints. For the cases where the closed-form solution is not obtained we provide lower bounds on it. In contrast to the previous works that have complexity issues, here, we provide simple privacy designs with low complexity which are based on finding the maximum singular value and singular vector of a matrix. To do so, we follow two approaches where in the first one we find a lower bound on the main problem and then approximate it, however, in the second approach we approximate the main problem directly.In this work, we present geometrical studies of the proposed methods and in a numerical example we compare our results considering both approaches with the optimal solution and the previous methods. Finally, we discuss how the proposed methods can be applied to deal with differential privacy.

title: Enhancing performance of VGG-16 for Classifying Dementia Through Synthesized Augmentation using Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Network
authors: Rajalakshmi Shenbaga Moorthy, Nandakumar Venkatesan, Sathish Kumar Kamaraj
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Dementia is a progressive neuro disorder affecting cognitive functions such as memory and reasoning. Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial for timely intervention. Deep learning models have shown promise in medical image classification. However, challenges such as class imbalance in datasets and lack of model interpretability affect the effectiveness of dementia diagnosis. A significant imbalance between healthy and dementia affected images lead to biased performance. Additionally, the functioning of a deep learning model is viewed as a black box, which limits its clinical adoption. This research aims to improve dementia classification and model interpretability by addressing the aforementioned limitations. Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Network (DCGAN) is utilized for synthetic data augmentation to balance the dataset. Gradient Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) is used to visualize the decision of the model. The Visual Geometry Group (VGG) - 16 based classifier is trained on a combined dataset (original + augmented) using categorical cross-entropy loss and Adam Optimizer. Performance of the classifier is evaluated through accuracy, precision, and recall. Similarly, the quality of the image is assessed through Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) and the Frechet Inception Distance (FID). Results indicate a significant improvement in classification accuracy with combined data yielding 95.63% validation accuracy when compared to $85.20 \%$ on the original dataset. Similarly, SSIM and FID scores prove the effectiveness of DCGAN-generated images in enhancing data diversity. The critical brain regions are highlighted through Grad-CAM, which proves the transparency of the model. These findings prove that integrating synthetic data augmentation and explainability techniques enhances both accuracy and interpretability in dementia diagnosis.

title: Design and Implementation of an xApp-based System for Jamming and Interference Mitigation
authors: Aurora Paz-Pérez, Julio Suárez Gómez, F. Javier Valera Sánchez, J. Joaquín Escudero-Garzás
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Security is one of main concerns in communications, and radio devices and nodes can be easily targeted through jamming attacks even considering the sophisticated security features of 5 G systems. This work presents a comprehensive system based on O-RAN that monitors the spectrum, detects the jamming signal, classifies it, and provides mitigation actions. At the core of our system is an xApp suite that interconnect four xApps, each of them implementing one functionality. We have validated the performance of the xApp suite by implementing it in a 5G O-RAN testbed based on open source libraries and general purpose hardware.

title: Quantum Federated Learning for Adaptive Intrusion Detection Systems in Software-Defined Networks
authors: Yousef Alfezea, Ameer Mohammed
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) form a critical component of the security infrastructure in Software-Defined Networks (SDN). However, they often need to strike a balance between high detection accuracy, real-time responsiveness, and adaptability. Furthermore, traditional IDS that operate at the controller level suffer from centralized bottlenecks and high false alarms for evolving threats. Thus, edge-assisted approaches have been proposed to alleviate some of these drawbacks. While emerging quantum-enhanced strategies can be employed to accelerate this process, this would require specialized hardware at the edge devices, which is either impractical or too cost-prohibitive. In this work, we apply Classical Client Quantum Federated Learning (CC-QFL) to adaptive resource-constrained SDN nodes that use classical shadow tomography to offload quantum model training and aggregation to a centralized quantum controller. The overhead of periodic retraining is significantly reduced and inference requires $0.1 \mu$ s per instance. CC-QFL is evaluated on the Edge IIoTset dataset consisting of 1,048,576 instances, achieving $83.2 \%$ accuracy, $86 \%$ precision, $95 \%$ recall, and a $91 \%$ F1-score. It takes only 2.8 ms per round to train, which is several orders of magnitude faster than conventional deep learning IDS. These results reveal that in dynamic SDN environments, CC-QFL provides ultra-low latency, scalable, and robust intrusion detection, opening up possibilities for quantum-driven enhancements in the responsiveness of SDN controllers.

title: On the Convergence Speed of Spatially Coupled LDPC Ensembles Under Window Decoding
authors: Qingqing Peng, Dongxu Chang, Guanghui Wang, Guiying Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: It is known that windowed decoding (WD) can effectively balance the performance and complexity of spatially coupled low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes. In this study, we show that information can propagate in a wave-like manner at a constant speed under WD. Additionally, we provide an upper bound for the information propagation speed on the binary erasure channel, which can assist in designing the number of iterations required within each window.

title: ECOMAR Project: Measurement Aspects for the Automation of Real-Time Sea Water Quality Analysis
authors: Enrico Petritoli, Eduardo De Francesco, Nicola Pio Belfiore, Sara Bobone, Giuseppe Schirripa Spagnolo, Simonetta Tuti, Mariagrazia Leccisi, Fabio Leccese
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: In this paper, we present work in progress toward a “water quality laboratory” that will be hosted and managed on an amphibious rover capable of moving on the water surface. The rover will be used to probe the state of water sea, lake, or similar body of water. We will analyze measurement aspects related to automation, including some design choices. Specifically, we discuss how to design a laboratory aimed at early warning by analyzing chemical and physical parameters, the multiparametric probes used to measure them, and their correlations, which enable the identification of specific types of macropollution. A preliminary implementation of the laboratory, developed according to these criteria, will be presented along with initial measurements..

title: Two-Way Relay Full duplex Layered Generalized Spatial Modulation with Physical-layer Network Coding
authors: K S Shafrin, Neelakandan Rajamohan
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: A novel two-way relay (TWR) using decode and forward (DF) architecture that integrates full-duplex (FD) communication with layered generalized spatial modulation (LGSM) using physical-layer network coding (PNC), termed TWR FDLGSM PNC, is proposed in this paper to significantly enhance spectral efficiency and system scalability in MIMO wireless networks. By enabling simultaneous bi-directional communication and leveraging multiple spatial layers with index-modulated antenna-symbol mapping, the proposed system supports highthroughput transmission. A dynamic antenna selection strategy ensures conflict-free layered transmission, while PNC is employed at the FD relay to combine received messages via XOR operations for efficient broadcast. We develop a comprehensive system, accounting for residual self-interference (RSI) and analyze performance through Monte Carlo simulations. Results demonstrate that TWR FD-LGSM PNC outperforms existing TWR FD-SM and TWR FD-GSM schemes in bit error rate (BER) performance, especially under limited hardware and imperfect SI cancellation, positioning it as a promising solution for next-generation spectrally-efficient MIMO systems.

title: HPC/AI Benchmarking in the Post-Moore Era: Evaluating Frameworks, Algorithms, Tools and Cross-Architecture Challenges
authors: Ahmed Abd El-Hameed, Aliaa Youssif
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: The slowing of Moore’s Law is driving major changes in High-Performance Computing (HPC) and Artificial Intelligence (AI), sparking the need for new ways to test performance across different types of hardware, energy use, and the merging of scientific and machine learning tasks. In this survey, We examined cutting-edge studies that cover a wide range of HPC and AI benchmarking, including well-known benchmark suites such as HPC AI500, MLPerf HPC, and AIPerf, as well as performance modeling, energy efficiency measures, and novel approaches, including surrogate benchmarking, optimizations for distributed training, and hybrid classical-quantum methods. We organized these findings into a clear framework by categorizing them as micro-kernel benchmarks, application-specific suites, and cross-architecture tools. This taxonomy provides practical insights and clear guidance for creating flexible, energy-efficient benchmarking standards that can adapt to the complexities of modern HPC and AI systems.

title: Implementation of the BHT quantum algorithm for finding collisions of a lightweight hash function on IBM “Sherbrooke” via Qiskit
authors: Nghi Nguyen Van, Minh Thang Vu, Hanh Tran Thi, Nam Hai Ngo, Ba Linh Vu, Van Duan Nguyen
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference On Cryptography And Information Security (VCRIS)
abstract: The Brassard–Høyer–Tapp (BHT) algorithm, introduced in 1997, demonstrates that cryptographic-hash collisions can be located with lower computational cost than classical brute-force search. Yet, no experimental realization of BHT for hash-function cryptanalysis on an actual quantum processor has been reported. In this paper, we present practical implementation and in-depth analysis of BHT applied to a lightweight cryptographic hash on IBM’s quantum hardware. Using Qiskit, we design the quantum circuit for the target hash and embed the BHT subroutines. Our results quantify both the algorithmic complexity and the number of qubit required for successful collision discovery, and they provide a roadmap for extending the technique to real-world hash functions once quantum resources scale to the necessary size.

title: Anisotropic Design of High-Performance Lattice Materials
authors: Jian Zhao, Jian Xiong
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: Being lightweight and high-performance are qualities often sought-after in practical engineering materials. Herein, this study introduce an anisotropic design analysis approach-employing a three-dimensional (3D) polar coordinate representation-to tailor the lattice's mechanical characteristics along specific directions. Specimens are printed utilizing composite fused filament fabrication (FFF). By integrating theoretical modeling, finite element analysis (FEA), and experimental method, this study verifies the efficacy of the approach in achieving superior mechanical properties along targeted orientations. The lattices exhibit significant improvements over the stretch-dominated Octet+Cubic lattice, with specific stiffness, specific strength, and specific energy absorption (SEA) enhanced by 105.0%, 154.2%, and 115.1%, respectively. The mechanical performance of these designs surpasses those of most recently reported lattices. In certain cases, the relative strength even exceeds the empirical upper limit predicted by the Gibson-Ashby model. This study presents a novel paradigm for the anisotropic design of high-performance architected materials.

title: Geological data acquisition and management for the cartography of submerged areas within the Italian CARG Mapping Project
authors: Andrea Fiorentino, Loredana Battaglini, Simone Orefice, Alessandra Pensa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: The Geological Survey of Italy is carrying out the geological mapping Project CARG which includes acquisition and representation of data from submerged areas until the shelfbreak. Guidelines and standards are established by the Geological Survey of Italy and are available online on the ISPRA website. Criteria adopted to characterize units in submerged areas are as much as possible the same used on land. Data in submerged areas are acquired at the $1: 25,000$ scale, by indirect surveys carried out by geophysical methods and must be groundtruthed by samplings, video inspections or scuba diving. Information to be represented on the geological maps refers to the distribution of deposits cropping out on the seafloor. Bathymetric data for the CARG Project are provided by the Hydrographic Institute of the Navy (IIMM) through the Geological Survey of Italy. Acoustic facies are interpreted by means of groundtruthing as the units cropping out on the seafloor, which are represented according to the standards of the geological map of Italy. Each type of information is classified according to the guidelines and is stored in a geological database at 1:25,000 scale, called BDG - Banca Dati Geologica. The CARG database is continuously updated and provide the opportunity to be implemented with new features and attributes as needed. Maps and the accompanying explanatory notes are available online as rasters and in digital format on the CARG-GATE platform (//progetto-carg.isprambiente.it/). The geological maps produced by the CARG Project constitute a solid base for further scientific studies as well as for spatial planning and land management.

title: Anti-jamming Strategy of Guaranteed Communication Reliability with Several Receivers
authors: Andrey Garnaev, Wade Trappe
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Due to the open nature of wireless channels, wireless networks are susceptible to various physical layer security threats, including interference from jamming attacks. Such jamming attacks may adversely affect communication and diminish the reliability of receiving essential data and commands. Such communication reliability is crucial when an operator controls mobile objects, as a reduction in the reliability of getting commands or information might lead to drastic consequences. Specifically, we consider a communication center equipped with multiple antennas to communicate with a group of receivers (say, drones) performing missions in separate zones. In each zone for its protection, a jammer is installed to disrupt the communication of the communication center with the corresponding receiver. As a metric of communication reliability, we consider the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) at the receiver. Since designing an anti-jamming strategy in such a hostile environment involves different agents, such as the communication center and the jammers, each with its own objectives, the problem is modeled within a game-theoretic framework. Traditionally, in such a background, the anti-jamming strategy aims to maximize the total SINR or throughput among all the receivers. A con of such a traditional approach is that, due to limited resources, the communication center might have to sacrifice communication with some receivers to maximize the total communication. This could compromise the joint mission as the receivers (drones) might face a lack of data. Motivated by this observation, we suggest using the minimal SINR among all the receivers as a communication metric for the group of receivers. This metric reflects the guaranteed reliability of communication with each receiver. In particular, we derive and illustrate an anti-jamming strategy in the most critical scenario for the communication node, where the communication node is unaware of the exact locations of the jammers but only their distributions, whereas the jammers know their location exactly.

title: Fuel-Optimal Multi-Phase Trajectory Optimization for Reusable Launch Vehicle
authors: Minzhao Wang, Qingzhong Gan, Xiaogang Wang, Hongyu Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: This paper addresses the critical challenge of fuel-optimal trajectory design for reusable launch vehicles during the return phase. Compared to existing researches focusing on the terminal vertical landing phase, the proposed method takes into account the multi-phase reentry problem encompassing the powered descent, low dynamic pressure, and final aerodynamic deceleration phases. To overcome multidimensional constraints such as fuel efficiency, path-dependent dynamic pressure limits, and terminal precise transition, a two-stage reentry framework is proposed. First, the Gauss pseudospectral method (GPM) is employed to generate the fuel-optimal trajectory by discretizing the nonlinear dynamics into a nonlinear programming problem; second, a model predictive control (MPC) strategy is designed to track the optimized reentry trajectory while accommodating disturbances and time-varying nonlinear dynamics. Numerical simulations will validate the proposed algorithm.

title: Preparation of a UAV Infrared Stealth Coating Based on Epoxy Modification
authors: Wei Pan, Niantong Rong, Kaiyang Zhang, Chi Zhang, Jirui Liu, Tianhui Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: As UAV speeds rise, the temperature of their hot - end components increases, boosting infrared radiation. This heightens the risk of UAVs being detected and identified by infrared sensors during flight. Thus, enhancing UAV infrared stealth in high - temperature settings has become a military hot topic. This study prepared an infrared stealth coating using liquid polysulfide rubber - modified epoxy resin as the substrate. The stealth effect of the optimal - formula coating was tested with a thermal infrared imager. Results show that the coating's infrared emissivity decreases with more aluminum powder. However, when over 30% aluminum powder is added, adhesion weakens. At 30% aluminum powder content, the coating has good physical and infrared - stealth properties.

title: Improved Neural Distinguisher for PRESENT-80 using Inception and Efficient Channel Attention in Related-Key Multi-Pair Setting
authors: Thanh-Phong Nguyen, Nguyen Tan Cam, Van-Than Huynh, Tan Nguyen, Hieu-Minh Nguyen
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference On Cryptography And Information Security (VCRIS)
abstract: This study presents a neural distinguisher for the lightweight block cipher PRESENT-80, targeting the related-key differential setting with multiple ciphertext pairs per sample. The proposed model combines an Inception-style multi-branch convolutional block, residual connections, and Efficient Channel Attention to extract richer differential features. Each input sample includes several ciphertext pairs encrypted under fixed differences in both plaintext and key, allowing the model to learn from structured ciphertext correlations across pairs. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms prior baselines from round 7 to 9 and retains distinguishing ability up to round 15, highlighting its robustness under deeper diffusion. This demonstrates the effectiveness of combining structured multi-pair inputs with lightweight attention mechanisms for data-constrained neural cryptanalysis.

title: Research on Civil Jet Aeroplane CO2 Emissions Metric
authors: Yi Yang, Jiwei Tang, Zihang Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: The CO2 emissions certification standard for aircraft has been reviewed in this paper, and the analysis process for CO2 emissions in the initial stage of aircraft design is provided. The CO2 metric value (MV) for civil jet aircraft has been estimated. The variation in CO2 emissions MV with Maximum Take-Off Weight (MTOW) and drag has then been analyzed to reduce CO2 emissions for a specific jet aeroplane. For the researched subsonic jet aeroplane, CO2 emissions MV is decreased by about 0.0062 if MTOW is lighten by 1000kg, and CO2 emissions MV is decreased 0.003 if drag coefficient is decreased 5 counts. Beyond 5 counts, for every 10 counts of drag coefficient reduction, the MV decreases by about 0.02.

title: Nonlinear Control Strategy of Six-Degree Parallel Motion Simulator Based on Inverse Dynamics Compensation
authors: Junshuo Shui, Liang Li, You Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: In the realm of aerospace engineering, accurately simulating the complex motion states of aerospace vehicles during ground tests is of paramount importance for ensuring their safety and performance. Owing to the duality between serial and parallel mechanisms, six-degree-of-freedom (6-DOF) parallel motion simulators have emerged as a crucial tool in this field, offering unique motion control characteristics that are highly beneficial for aerospace vehicle ground test simulations. Traditional control methods typically control the driving mechanisms of the six-degree-of-freedom motion simulator separately, without integrating the system structural information contained in the simulator's dynamic model into the controller design. To address this issue, this paper proposes a nonlinear adaptive control strategy based on inverse dynamic compensation. This strategy is designed through virtual control input and by employing the Backstepping method, introduces the dynamic properties of the simulator and the dynamic characteristics of the driving mechanism into the controller design, thereby overcoming the influence of model parameter uncertainties on system performance. Simulation results validate the correctness of the theoretical analysis and the effectiveness of the control method, demonstrating its potential for enhancing the accuracy and reliability of 6-DOF parallel motion simulators in aerospace vehicle ground test simulations.

title: Modeling and Simulation of UAV-Based IoT Links Under Fading and Shadowing Conditions
authors: Zahraa H. Mohamed, M. R. Wafaa Shakir, Zeinab Mhanna, Maher Rebai
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: In this work, we provide an extensive performance evaluation of a UAV-based, dual-hop Internet of Things (IoT) communication system that uses a decode-and-forward (DF) relaying protocol. We derive a closed-form expression for the outage probability under a Generalized-K (GK) composite channel model, which captures small-scale multipath fading, large-scale shadowing, and path loss. The analytical findings are further validated by extensive simulations, confirming the accuracy and robustness of the proposed model. Numerical results demonstrate that increasing the number of IoT devices significantly improves system reliability, emphasizing the critical role of conditions such as fading severity and transmission distance in communication performance. These findings provide valuable insights into the design of reliable UAV-based IoT networks in dynamic and challenging environments.

title: Benchmarking Ultra-Low-Power μNPUs
authors: Josh Millar, Yushan Huang, Sarab Sethi, Hamed Haddadi, Anil Madhavapeddy
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: None

title: Understanding and Characterizing Intermediate Paths of Email Delivery: The Hidden Dependencies
authors: Ruixuan Li, Chaoyi Lu, Baojun Liu, Yanzhong Lin, Haixin Duan, Qingfeng Pan, Jun Shao
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 ACM Internet Measurement Conference
abstract: In the cloud era, hosting-based email services have become a common business model. Various entities can participate in the email delivery process. However, the intermediate paths of email delivery have received little attention. In particular, the vulnerabilities and centralization of email intermediate paths have already posed real-world security threats. This paper conducts the first systematic analysis of intermediate paths of email delivery, aiming to understand dependence patterns and characterize the centralization. In collaboration with a large email service provider, we collected Received headers from email reception logs spanning nine months and reconstructed the complete intermediate paths of 105M clean emails. Our results reveal that Microsoft is the dominant provider of intermediate paths, participating in 66.4% of emails. We find that 86.9M (82.7%) emails rely on third-party providers in intermediate paths, and 9.1M (8.7%) paths involve multiple providers. Email signature providers frequently appear in cross-vendor intermediate paths. In addition, we reveal significant differences in the regional dependencies and centralization of email intermediate paths across countries and continents. The centralization observed in email intermediate paths also differs from incoming and outgoing servers. We hope our work prompts more attention to email intermediate paths to enhance the security of the email ecosystem.

title: Poster: Contactless Cardiovascular Hemodynamics Inference and Hypertension Detection via Ballistocardiogram
authors: Yandao Huang, Cong Li, Chenggao Li, Lin Chen, Junyao Peng, Qian Zhang, Kaishun Wu
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Hypertension affects 1.28 billion adults, but blood pressure alone is insufficient for accurate hypertension detection. In this paper, we identified a range of multi-dimensional hemodynamics as novel biomarkers that can offer more comprehensive cardiovascular insights for detecting hypertension. We design a novel system that collects ballistocardiogram (BCG) signals from an optic fiber sensor mat. It features a multi-task, multi-branch, unsupervised domain adaptation learning framework, enabling simultaneous prediction of five hemodynamic biomarkers for hypertension detection. In a 4-month trial with 85 subjects, Hyde achieved 97.65% average accuracy for hypertension detection.

title: Poster: Bridging Autonomy and Connectivity: Enabling Smart Vehicle Communication via Full Self-Driving Models
authors: Zhicheng Wang, Shihan Zhao, Donghui Dai, Lei Yang
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on Full Self-Driving (FSD) models for perception and trajectory planning. However, their wireless communication systems face significant challenges in dynamic environments, particularly evident in beamforming dependent vehicle-to-satellite links. Motivated by the powerful sensing capabilities of autonomous vehicles, we introduce Full Smart-Communication (FSC), a unified framework that reuses intermediate outputs from FSD pipelines—such as planned trajectories, occupancy maps, and 3D posture estimates—to model the spatio-temporal radio environment. To avoid accessing raw sensor data directly, FSC leverages processed semantic and kinematic information to anticipate channel conditions and proactively compute beamforming parameters ahead of time. Tested in realistic driving datasets, FSC improves signal strength by up to 15 dB. FSC bridges the gap between autonomous perception and robust communication, enabling proactive, low-latency, and energy-efficient connectivity.

title: Unmasking the Shadow Economy: A Deep Dive into Drainer-as-a-Service Phishing on Ethereum
authors: Bowen He, Yufeng Hu, Zhuo Chen, Yuan Chen, Ting Yu, Rui Chang, Lei Wu, Yajin Zhou
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 ACM Internet Measurement Conference
abstract: The prosperity of Ethereum gives rise to a new type of transaction-based phishing scam. Specifically, users are tempted to visit phishing websites and sign phishing transactions that allow scammers to withdraw their tokens. Meanwhile, to accelerate the deployment of phishing websites, scammers have introduced a business model, Drainer-as-a-Service (DaaS). In this model, drainer operators focus on crafting specialized phishing toolkits, named ''wallet drainers'', while drainer affiliates handle the deployment and promotion of phishing websites. After stealing victims' tokens, they will distribute profits. In this paper, we present the first systematic study of DaaS on Ethereum. To begin with, we propose a snowball sampling approach to build the first large-scale DaaS dataset, including 1,910 profit sharing contracts, 56 operator accounts, 6,087 affiliate accounts, and 87,077 profit-sharing transactions. Then, we analyze the scale of DaaS from the perspectives of victims, operators, and affiliates, and perform clustering analysis to uncover dominant DaaS families. Finally, we reported DaaS accounts in the dataset and 32,819 phishing websites deployed with DaaS toolkits to the community. Our work aims to serve as a guide for Ethereum service providers to enhance user protection against DaaS.

title: Poster: The Potential of Erroneous Outbound Traffic Analysis to Unveil Silent Internal Anomalies
authors: Andrea Sordello, Zhihao Wang, Kai Huang, Alessandro Cornacchia, Marco Mellia
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 ACM Internet Measurement Conference
abstract: Network administrators have long relied on passive measurement to detect malicious activity, diagnose misconfigurations, and ensure network health. Under the assumption that threats and issues originate externally, prior studies [1] have predominantly focused on the analysis of inbound traffic — i.e., traffic initiated by external hosts and targeting internal destinations. Conversely, outbound traffic — i.e., originating from internal hosts toward external destinations — has received comparatively less attention, despite carrying strong indicators of security-relevant anomalies [2].

title: Poster: Optimized Cache Pollution Attack: A DDoS Vector in Content Delivery Networks
authors: Jiaqi Liu, Noriaki Kamiyama
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking
abstract: Content Delivery Network (CDN) enhances Internet scalability and resilience against traditional Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks by deploying cached edge servers close to end-users. However, CDNs remain vulnerable to unique attack vectors, such as cache pollution attack (CPA). While existing research focuses on attack detection and mitigation, this paper investigates optimized CPA strategies from an adversarial perspective, specifically targeting CDN origin servers to bypass edge server defenses and amplify DDoS impacts. We analyze the attack mechanisms, evaluate performance degradation under varying CPA parameters, and quantify the scalability of this DDoS vector. Experimental results demonstrate that optimized CPA can exhaust origin server resources with fewer malicious requests, highlighting a pressing need for robust CDN architectural countermeasures.

title: Robust and Energy-Efficient Multi-user OFDM-CVCSK Paired Transceiver via Matrix Recovery
authors: Zuwei Chen, Hing Cheung So, Zhi-Yong Wang, Zhaofeng Liu, Lin Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a robust, energy-efficient multi-user OFDM chaotic vector cyclic shift keying (MU-OFDM-CVCSK) system for channels impaired by multi-user interference (MUI), Gaussian, and impulsive noise. The system’s co-designed transceiver uses cyclic shifts of a single reference signal for energy efficiency, while a novel receiver combines low-rank matrix factorization with a truncated-quadratic loss function to suppress both MUI and noise. In particular, the transmitted signal’s cyclical structure enables iterative reference refinement, further enhancing performance. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the algorithm’s convergence, complexity, energy efficiency, power spectral density, peak-to-average power ratio, and derive the bit error rate (BER) expressions. Simulations demonstrate superior BER performance compared to benchmark schemes in challenging interference and noise conditions.

title: Cardiac Output Quantification via Esophageal Photoplethysmography and Deep Learning
authors: Leyang Zhao, Junyue Zhuang, Quanzhen Jiang, Bo Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Continuous minimally invasive cardiac output (CO) measurement via photoplethysmography (PPG) has received much attention in daily monitoring. However, the precision of current research is not suitable for the clinical measurement of CO. Therefore, a novel cardiac output quantification model is proposed that adopts esophageal PPG signals for clinical monitoring. Based on this model, a continuous CO quantification instrument is made and an experiment is designed to obtain the training and testing data set of the model. The experimental data set consists of 421 paired observations. These observations are from the esophageal PPG data obtained with the custom-made instrument and PICCO (Pulse Index Continuous Cardiac Output) data obtained with a commercial instrument in seven pigs. In the proposed model, a deep learning algorithm is designed for CO quantification. A four-layer perceptron model is developed based on a mathematical analysis of 24 features from the experimental data set. Meanwhile, the best wavelength, 940 nm, is determined to improve the prediction quality via the random forest model. The custom-made continuous CO quantification instrument, evaluated with a ten-fold cross-validation, demonstrates a correlation coefficient of 0.934, indicating a high predictive precision. The consistency of the instrument is verified through Bland-Altman analysis, and the results show a Percentage Error (PE) of 0.0803 and a Percentage of estimates within consistency limit (PEI) of 0.965, indicating good consistency.

title: SKYLINK: Scalable and Resilient Link Management in LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Wanja De Sombre, Arash Asadi, Debopam Bhattacherjee, Deepak Vasisht, Andrea Ortiz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: The rapid growth of space-based services has established Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite networks as a promising option for global broadband connectivity. Next-generation LEO networks leverage inter-satellite links (ISLs) to provide faster and more reliable communications compared to traditional bent-pipe architectures, even in remote regions. However, the high mobility of satellites, dynamic traffic patterns, and potential link failures pose significant challenges for efficient and resilient routing. To address these challenges, we model the LEO satellite network as a time-varying graph comprising a constellation of satellites and ground stations. Our objective is to minimize a weighted sum of average delay and packet drop rate. Each satellite independently decides how to distribute its incoming traffic to neighboring nodes in real time. Given the infeasibility of finding optimal solutions at scale, due to the exponential growth of routing options and uncertainties in link capacities, we propose SKYLINK, a novel fully distributed learning strategy for link management in LEO satellite networks. SKYLINK enables each satellite to adapt to the time-varying network conditions, ensuring real-time responsiveness, scalability to millions of users, and resilience to network failures, while maintaining low communication overhead and computational complexity. To support the evaluation of SKYLINK at global scale, we develop a new simulator for large-scale LEO satellite networks. For 25.4 million users, SKYLINK reduces the weighted sum of average delay and drop rate by 29% compared to the bent-pipe approach, and by 92% compared to Dijkstra. It lowers drop rates by 95% relative to k-shortest paths, 99% relative to Dijkstra, and 74% compared to the bent-pipe baseline, while achieving up to 46% higher throughput. At the same time, SKYLINK maintains constant computational complexity with respect to constellation size.

title: Robust Bidding Strategy for Solar-Wind-Battery Virtual Power Plants in Ancillary Service Markets
authors: Khalil Gholami, Mohammad Taufiqul Arif, Md Enamul Haque
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: The increasing penetration of intermittent renewable energy sources (RESs) in the power grids has led to greater frequency deviation and reduced system strength. Therefore, ancillary services are introduced to stabilize the grid and dampen RES-induced fluctuations. To comply with the directives of the Australian energy market operator (AEMO), this paper proposes a novel strategy that enables virtual power plants (VPPs) comprising solar, wind, and battery storage systems to engage in both energy and Australian ancillary services, encompassing two regulations and six contingency services. Additionally, to address uncertainties, a robust and time-efficient technique is used that is compatible with the dynamic nature of ancillary service provisions. The proposed model is evaluated through case studies using a range of battery storage systems introduced by the commonwealth scientific and industrial research organization (CSIRO), along with real-world cases from Victoria, Australia. Results demonstrate that VPP participation in both energy and ancillary service markets yields a 19.31% higher profit compared to the energy market alone.

title: Real-Time Monitoring and Safety Scheduling of Intelligent Elevators Based on Biometric Data Analysis
authors: Jie Yu, Bo Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Traditional elevator group control systems face limitations in terms of response speed, passenger recognition, and safety. To address these issues, this study proposes an intelligent real-time monitoring and safety dispatch model based on biometric data analysis. At the perception layer, a You Only Look Once (YOLO) recognition network integrated with the Ghost module and Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) is constructed. This hybrid architecture aims to achieve high-precision recognition of special passengers, such as wheelchair users and baby strollers. At the scheduling layer, a multi-objective optimization function is designed that considers passenger waiting time, energy consumption, and service fairness. Additionally, a Graph Neural Network (GNN) is enhanced via Ant Colony Optimization to implement differentiated, adaptive elevator dispatch strategies. At the control and simulation layer, various elevator usage scenarios are simulated using a Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) and the Totally Integrated Automation (TIA) Portal platform to evaluate the system’s response efficiency and safety. At the control and simulation layer, various elevator usage scenarios are simulated using a PLC and the TIA Portal platform to evaluate system response effectiveness. Experimental results on the Visual Object Classes 2007 dataset demonstrate that the proposed YOLO-World-Ghost-CBAM biometric recognition model achieves the highest accuracy for identifying special passengers. Specifically, it reaches a 97.4% recognition accuracy for wheelchair users, representing a 5.1% improvement over the YOLO-World-Ghost model; a 95.6% accuracy for baby strollers, improving by 6.5%; 10.7% over the YOLO-World model, and 18.9% over the conventional YOLOv8 model. Compared with other scheduling models, the GNN model optimized via the ant colony algorithm performs consistently well across various scenarios. Under simulation condition A, it achieves optimal scheduling with the shortest time cost (20.73s) and the lowest energy consumption (33,807.5J). Under conditions B and C, it also maintains high scheduling efficiency with relatively low time costs (24.72s and 35.18s) and energy consumption (32,067.6J and 37,801.7J), validating the effectiveness and generalization capability of Ant Colony Optimization in multi-objective scheduling. This study innovatively integrates biometric recognition with intelligent scheduling, offering a safer, more efficient, and user-centric elevator system solution for smart building environments.

title: Using Tactile Charts to Support Comprehension and Learning of Complex Visualizations for Blind and Low-Vision Individuals
authors: Tingying He, Maggie McCracken, Daniel Hajas, Sarah Creem-Regehr, Alexander Lex
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: We investigate whether tactile charts support comprehension and learning of complex visualizations for blind and low-vision (BLV) individuals and contribute four tactile chart designs and an interview study. Visualizations are powerful tools for conveying data, yet BLV individuals typically can rely only on assistive technologies—primarily alternative texts—to access this information. Prior research shows the importance of mental models of chart types for interpreting these descriptions, yet BLV individuals have no means to build such a mental model based on images of visualizations. Tactile charts show promise to fill this gap in supporting the process of building mental models. Yet studies on tactile data representations mostly focus on simple chart types, and it is unclear whether they are also appropriate for more complex charts as would be found in scientific publications. Working with two BLV researchers, we designed 3D-printed tactile template charts with exploration instructions for four advanced chart types: UpSet plots, violin plots, clustered heatmaps, and faceted line charts. We then conducted an interview study with 12 BLV participants comparing whether using our tactile templates improves mental models and understanding of charts and whether this understanding translates to novel datasets experienced through alt texts. Thematic analysis shows that tactile models support chart type understanding and are the preferred learning method by BLV individuals. We also report participants' opinions on tactile chart design and their role in BLV education.

title: Robust Condensing for LPV-MPC with Asymptotically Constant Complexity
authors: Gionata Cimini, Alberto Bemporad
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: This paper presents a highly efficient method for robustly eliminating equality constraints in optimization problems arising from Model Predictive Control (MPC). Such a condensing operation is often implemented to reduce the number of optimization variables through the direct elimination of state variables by substitution, a procedure which is prone to numerical instability and whose complexity scales linearly with the prediction horizon. We propose a novel blocked QR decomposition algorithm for condensing MPC problems in a numerically robust manner. The method is applicable when the system dynamics, described by either linear or linearized models, are time-invariant over the prediction horizon. The method effectively handles unstable dynamics and exhibits numerical convergence properties that result in an asymptotically constant computational complexity regardless of the horizon length. We benchmark our method against state-of-the-art algorithms for robust condensing of dynamic optimization problems, demonstrating significantly superior results. For sufficiently long horizons, the proposed algorithm can even outperform direct state elimination in terms of speed.

title: Robust Monocular Visual Odometry Via Dual-Paradigm Curriculum Learning
authors: Assaf Lahiany, Oren Gal
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Monocular visual odometry (VO) is accurate in controlled settings yet drifts sharply under aggressive motion and sensor noise. We offer a fundamental rethinking of VO robustness as a training-schedule problem rather than an architectural challenge, introducing a novel dual-paradigm curriculum learning framework that operates at both trajectory and loss-component levels. (i) A motion-based curriculum orders trajectories by measured motion complexity. (ii) A hierarchical component curriculum adaptively re-weights optical-flow, pose, and rotation losses via Self-Paced and in-training Reinforcement Learning (RL) schedulers. Integrated into an unmodified DPVO baseline, these strategies cut TartanAir ATE by 33% with only 31% extra training wall-time, and reach baseline accuracy 47% faster (Self-Paced). Without fine-tuning, the same models improve zero-shot performance on EuRoC (13% ATE reduction), TUM-RGBD (9%; 46% on dynamic scenes), KITTI (21%), and ICL-NUIM (32%). We show that explicit difficulty progression or adaptive loss weighting provides a practical, zero-inference-overhead path to robust monocular VO and could extend to other geometric vision tasks.

title: Double Closed-Loop Adaptive Position Control Method for Continuum Robot With Soft Drives
authors: Shiying Zhao, Qingxin Meng, Xuzhi Lai, Jinhua She, Edwardo F. Fukushima, Min Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: Continuum robots (CRs) show great potential in complex environments due to their excellent deformability. For practical applications, the position control of the CRs is an important research field. The common drives of the CRs are rigid motors with mature control schemes. However, the driving force of the rigid motors is often impactive, which may cause safety concerns during interaction. Soft drives based on pneumatic soft actuators (PSAs) can provide compliant driving force for the CRs robot bodies to solve this problem, but it is necessary to comprehensively consider the control of the soft drives and the robot bodies. This article takes a CR with soft drives as the research objective, and proposes a double closed-loop adaptive position control method to achieve the endpoint position control of the CR. This CR includes a length-variable robot body with millimeter-scale diameter and pneumatic soft drives. The kinematic model of the robot body is built based on the piecewise constant curvature (PCC) method, and the static models of the soft drives are derived from the three-element model. Based on these models, we propose a double closed-loop adaptive position control method. The inner loop is used to control the displacements of the soft drives, and the outer loop combines the endpoint position control with the nonsingular fast terminal sliding mode function to adaptively control the endpoint position based on the inner loop. By Lyapunov method, we prove the convergence of the endpoint position error. The effectiveness of the proposed control method is verified through experiments.

title: Coordinated Downlink Beamforming in Multi-Cell MIMO Networks: A Diffusion Model-Enhanced Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Perspective
authors: Haoqiang Liu, Huiming Chen, Wenzhen Huang, Zhaobin Wei, Yonghong Zeng, Hong Yan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: To address the surge in wireless traffic, multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technology has become essential for advancing communication systems. Within MIMO cellular networks, coordinated beamforming (CBF), achieved through the collaborative design of beamformers across multiple base stations (BSs), presents a promising strategy for enhancing network performance. However, in large-scale multi-cell, multi-user MIMO environments, optimizing beamforming coordination remains challenging due to high-dimensional spaces and dynamic conditions. While centralized, optimization-based CBF algorithms provide near-optimal solutions, their dependence on real-time global channel state information (CSI) and high computational complexity renders them impractical for dynamic networks. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a diffusion model-enhanced multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) coordinated beamforming framework, termed Diffusion-enhanced MACBF, which enables BSs to determine optimal beamformers independently based on partial observations. Key innovations of this framework include: firstly, a novel limited-information exchange protocol that facilitates effective coordination among BSs with minimal communication overhead; secondly, the introduction of a diffusion model-enhanced Multi-agent Soft Actor-Critic (MASAC) algorithm that enables BSs to efficiently manage spatial and temporal variations in large-scale scenarios; and thirdly, an optimized network architecture combining an Encoder, Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) layers to accurately map partial observations to optimal actions. Extensive simulations demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed algorithm, achieving an average rate of 7.5502 bps/Hz with up to 10.66% improvement over existing methods while significantly reducing information exchange requirements.

title: Unequal Content: search engine personalization influences exposure to information regarding the Israel-Palestine conflict
authors: Íris Damião, José M. Reis, Paulo Almeida, Nuno Santos, Joana Gonçalves-Sá
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Search engines serve as primary gateways to information, and users tend to trust them, despite being algorithmic black boxes and customizing results in non-transparent ways. Personalization, such as tailoring content based on a user’s location, is useful for routine content searches (e.g., finding nearby restaurants). However, this same personalization becomes problematic - and potentially harmful - when users seek information on sensitive or contentious geopolitical topics. In this work, we present the first large-scale measurement of how search engine curation and personalization affect users across different countries with distinct regional, political, and cultural traits. We developed a novel, privacy-preserving, bot-based methodology that simulates online user profiles embedded with cumulative regional traits. These customized bots were deployed from different locations and conducted identical searches, either on the Israel-Palestine conflict (e.g. “Hamas”) or neutral queries (e.g. “dinner recipe”), using both Google and DuckDuckGo. Our study addresses two main questions: (1) How do search results for the same query differ across countries, and which factors drive these differences?; and (2) Does personalization vary more significantly for conflict-related or for general queries? Our findings show that search result rankings are significantly influenced by location, interface language, and simulated browsing context, with the strongest effects observed for conflict-related queries. In many cases, these differences led to non-neutral portrayals of the same event, depending on the user’s presumed region. These results highlight how search engine personalization can shape public understanding of global events, creating fragmented or biased informational environments. This underscores the importance of educating users about the invisible filters that influence their access to information and, from a policy standpoint, these findings reveal a pressing need for greater transparency and accountability in how search engines personalize politically sensitive content. This is especially urgent given their outsized role in shaping democratic discourse and public opinion worldwide.

title: RVGICP: Fast and Accurate 4D Radar Point Cloud Registration Based on Voxelized GICP
authors: Feipeng Chen, Lihui Wang, Kui Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Point cloud registration is crucial for autonomous vehicle Radar-based localization, mapping, and perception. Compared to conventional Radar, 4D Radar offers enhanced elevation information, facilitating the generation of 3D point cloud akin to LiDAR. However, the inherent sparsity and high noise level of 4D Radar data make direct adaptation of LiDAR-based registration methods ineffective. To address these challenges, we propose Radar Voxelized Generalized Iterative Closest Point (RVGICP) algorithm for efficient and rapid point cloud registration. First, we introduce a dual-stage initial pose estimation module. To robustly handle large inter-scan displacements, it leverages Doppler velocity for an initial translation estimate. Complementing this, an efficient rotation estimation method based on point cloud histograms is proposed to accelerate convergence and mitigate the risk of local minima. Second, we extend the voxelized generalized iterative closest point (VGICP) algorithm by performing voxelization in the polar coordinates, enabling adaptive resolution for voxel matching. Third, a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$ 3^{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-neighbors set based voxel covariance estimation model is proposed, which better characterizes local geometric properties and avoids computationally nearest neighbor search. Extensive experiments on both open-source datasets and our experimental vehicle demonstrate that RVGICP achieves superior accuracy and robustness across various weather conditions while maintaining high computational efficiency.
