title: A Survey on Navigation Technologies of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Swarm
authors: Liangbin Zhang, Weisheng Chen, Jing Chang, Yuntao Xue
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: This survey concisely maps the new progress of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) swarm navigation in the past five years. A comparative analysis of the most relevant and adopted methods is done to understand their main strengths and limitations. This paper also focuses on some new technologies that have been successfully applied in other agent fields and have good application prospects in UAV swarms but have not yet been implemented. In light of the analysis results, this paper presents open issues and research challenges associated with UAV swarm navigation at the present stage. Through the analysis of the challenges encountered, it becomes possible to formulate the research directions in the future. Overall, this paper serves as a comprehensive guide for designing localization and path planning methods for UAV swarms, aiding researchers in selecting the most suitable methods for their swarm navigation needs.

title: Geomorphological study of the Abruzzo coastal area, Central Italy ARENA RESEARCH preliminary results
authors: Balsa Milojkovic, Giorgio Paglia, Vania Mancinelli, Anna Grazia De Flaviis, Marcello D’Alberto, Elena Romano, Roberta Ivaldi, Enrico Miccadei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: The ARENA RESEARCH project analyzes the geomorphological and physical features of the Abruzzo coastal area, Central Italy, by a multidisciplinary point of view. The research encompasses a review of the available geothematic information, the realization of a comprehensive Geodatabase, the geomorphological field surveys and activities, and a GISbased reconstruction of coastal feature dynamics from 1955 to 2020. The preliminary results, related to the coastline changes, topographic maps and surveys, orthophotos, and technical regional data allowed the identification of erosion and progradation zones, influenced by the interaction between climate changes and natural and anthropic processes. The final goal of this research is to construct thematic maps, Atlas of Abruzzo Beaches and specific guidelines useful for sustainable territorial planning and coastal management strategies in a changing environment. Moreover, it can act as a tool to effectively support policymakers, and all interested stakeholders, in reducing impacts arising from coastal hazards.

title: Temperature Stress and Contact Resistance Study of Electrical Connectors in Mars Temperature Environment
authors: Dong Hou, Xiangjin Zhang, Ruiqi Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: Electrical connectors are vital for reliable signal transmission in Martian sample return missions, where their performance directly impacts system stability under extreme environmental conditions. The Martian surface, characterized by temperatures ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-120^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 80° C and diurnal variations of approximately 100° C, poses significant challenges to connector reliability due to thermal stress and material degradation. This study introduces a novel high-reliability surface-mount electrical connector designed for Mars exploration, featuring a spherical composite structure with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 5.51^{\circ}$</tex> deflection compensation and reduced mating force. Through multi-physics coupling simulations using COMSOL, we analyze the thermal stress distribution, temperature gradients, and contact resistance dynamics under Martian temperature conditions. Experimental validation confirms that the connector maintains stable contact resistance, with a fitted temperature-resistance model achieving a prediction error of less than 3% at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>. The proposed design demonstrates enhanced reliability, offering a 15% reduction in contact area degradation under prolonged low-temperature cycling and a 40% decrease in mating force compared to conventional designs. These findings provide practical guidance for developing robust electrical connectors for deep space exploration.

title: Dual-Domain Exponent of Maximum Mutual Information Decoding
authors: Seyed AmirPouya Moeini, Albert Guillén i Fàbregas
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: This paper provides a dual domain derivation of the error exponent of maximum mutual information (MMI) decoding with constant composition codes, showing it coincides with that of maximum likelihood decoding for discrete memoryless channels. The analysis is further extended to joint source-channel coding, demonstrating that the generalized MMI decoder achieves the same random coding error exponent as the maximum a posteriori decoder.

title: Remote Channel Synthesis
authors: Yassine Hamdi, Deniz Gündüz
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We consider the problem of synthesizing a memoryless channel between an unobserved source and a remote terminal. An encoder has access to a partial or noisy version Z<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> = (Z<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>, …,Z<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</inf>) of a remote source sequence X<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> = (X<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>, …,X<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</inf>), with (X<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf>,Z<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf>) independent and identically distributed with joint distribution q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">X,Z</inf>. The encoder communicates through a noiseless link to a decoder which aims to produce an output Y <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> coordinated with the remote source; that is, the total variation distance between the joint distribution of X<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> and Y <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> and some i.i.d. target distribution $q_{X,Y}^{ \otimes n}$ is required to vanish as n goes to infinity. The two terminals may have access to a source of rate-limited common randomness. We present a single-letter characterization of the optimal compression and common randomness rates. We also show that when the common randomness rate is small, then in most cases, coordinating Z<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> and Y <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> using a standard channel synthesis scheme is strictly sub-optimal. In other words, schemes for which the joint distribution of Z<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> and Y <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sup> approaches a product distribution asymptotically are strictly sub-optimal.

title: Adaptive Intelligent Disturbance Rejection Control for Cross-Domain Hypersonic Vehicles
authors: GuoQun Liu, YuLiang Bai
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: To address adaptive disturbance rejection control challenges for hypersonic vehicles operating across large-span airspaces and wide-speed ranges, this study proposes a neural network estimation-based adaptive intelligent control strategy. The methodology overcomes highly dynamic, strongly coupled, and uncertain flight conditions through three critical advancements: 1) Development of a global dynamic model via multi-dimensional constraint mapping across motion, attitude, and temporal domains; 2) Integration of neural networks with a composite disturbance observer that simultaneously compensates for aerodynamic uncertainties, network approximation errors, and input matrix deviations; 3) Derivation of a finite-time convergent control law guaranteeing precise command signal tracking. Mathematical simulations validate the framework's effectiveness in resolving cross-domain flight control challenges, confirming robust disturbance rejection across the specified operational envelope.

title: Disturbance-Resilient Cooperative Control of UAV Swarms Based on a Multi-Agent Leader-Follower Architecture
authors: Xiaobo Wei
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of cooperative control for UAV swarms in complex wind field environments by proposing a hybrid control method that integrates dynamic role assignment and adaptive disturbance rejection. Inspired by the autonomous leader-switching behavior in migrating geese, a distributed architecture is developed based on local neighbor information exchange. The leading UAVs are dynamically selected based on energy consumption and tracking error, while follower UAVs employ an improved PID controller for trajectory tracking. To counteract unknown wind disturbances, an online gradient-based disturbance observer is developed with an error-dependent learning rate to avoid chattering, a common issue in traditional sliding mode control. Two levels of simulation are conducted for validation: First, Python-based numerical si mulations are used to verify the core logic with particle dynamics and stochastic wind fields; second, rigid-body dynamics simulations are conducted in PyBullet using open-source UAV models to demonstrate feasibility. Results show that under wind speeds of 15 m/s (equivalent to Beaufort scale 7), the proposed method maintains a formation tracking error within 0.3 m for a swarm of ten UAVs, while reducing communication load to 40% of conventional methods. This provides a viable cooperative control solution for UAV swarms in high-disturbance environments.

title: Thermo-Mechanical Coupled Aging Behavior and Modeling of HTPB Propellant Under Constant Strain Conditions
authors: Pengju Qin, Xiangyu Zhang, Kai Jiang, Jiming Cheng
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: In this study, the effects of accelerated ageing under thermo-mechanical coupled on the maximum elongation of HTPB propellants were investigated. The research results show that under thermo-mechanical coupled conditions, the maximum elongation rate exhibits a two-stage characteristic of first increasing and then decreasing. Based on experimental data, a modified Arrhenius model was established, introducing a strain correction coefficient to quantify the reduction effect of mechanical work on activation energy. Combined with finite element analysis, the change in the maximum elongation rate of a certain type of solid motor grain under storage temperature spectrum was derived.

title: QUIC Traffic Identification in Kernel Space
authors: Kokthay Poeng, Laurent Schumacher, Sereysethy Touch
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: QUIC is a transport-layer protocol that encrypts most headers and all payload data, encapsulating them in UDP to provide security and low latency. However, this encryption and encapsulation pose challenges for kernel-level network and security monitoring. To address this, we present LinkQUIC, the first heuristic-based system that identifies and classifies QUIC traffic at both kernel-space endpoints and middleboxes. LinkQUIC analyzes unencrypted QUIC header fields and leverages gaps in existing QUIC implementations, particularly during connection migration and path changes where behavior does not fully comply with RFC 9000’s privacy-preserving guidelines. Unlike user space tools, By leveraging eBPF, LinkQUIC operates entirely in kernel space without requiring kernel modifications, encryption keys or prior knowledge of specific QUIC deployments. We evaluate LinkQUIC in real-world environments and demonstrate its effectiveness in identifying QUIC traffic, including complex migration scenarios, with minimal overhead.

title: An Enhanced Exploration GRASP-Based Algorithm for Virtual Network Embedding
authors: Amine Rguez, Yassine Hadjadj-Aoul, Gerardo Rubino
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: With the rise of distributed clouds and Virtualized functions, Virtual Network Embedding (VNE) has become a key challenge in enabling network slicing. Several approaches exist in the literature to tackle such a problem; some of them (e.g., heuristics) converge quickly to a local minimum, while others are not explainable and, therefore, do not provide the necessary guarantees for their deployment in a real network (e.g., artificial intelligence-based techniques). In this paper, we propose an enhanced GRASP-based algorithm that efficiently explores the solution space using a broader candidate selection and deeper local search. The simulation results show the potential of the proposed method for solving services’ placement problems and its superiority over some heuristics in terms of placement success rate and the Revenue to the Cost (R/C) metric.

title: Study on Load Reduction Characteristics of Sandwich-Structured Head Cap During High-Speed Water Entry
authors: Xuanchen Li, Yao Shi, Qiaogao Huang, Guang Pan, Hairui Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: To address the significant hardening effect and insufficient energy absorption efficiency of traditional monolithic buffer head caps during high-speed water entry of large vessels, this paper proposes a novel sandwich-structured buffer head cap. The structure consists of carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP) panels combined with a multilayer gradient aluminium foam core. A numerical model of the sandwich structure is developed using the arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian (ALE) multiphase coupling algorithm, which is used to analyze its load-reduction mechanism. The results demonstrate that the layered design of the sandwich structure effectively homogenizes plastic deformation through stress concentration. By sacrificing part of the instantaneous acceleration reduction capacity, it achieves a longer structural response time and more uniform load distribution, thereby improving the overall load reduction performance.

title: Assessing the correlation of soil properties and groundwater quality in coastal aquifers
authors: Maria Rosaria Alfio, Piero Mastrorilli, Gabriella Balacco, Maria Dolores Fidelibus, Maria Michela Dell’Anna, Matilda Mali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for the Sea; Learning to Measure Sea Health Parameters (MetroSea)
abstract: A qualitative approach was adopted to assess the impact of soil mineralogy on the quality of groundwater in a coastal aquifer. This approach incorporates chemical and physicochemical data from soil and groundwater, as well as multivariate statistical analysis. Concurrent investigations of the soil and groundwater were employed to ensure consistent and comparable data, providing a comprehensive understanding of the interactions between soil properties and groundwater quality. Metal pollution was monitored in both the soil and the water at a highly contaminated Site of National Interest in southern Italy. Using a combined approach provided valuable insights into the interrelated factors influencing metal mobility from soil to water, including soil pH, texture, and organic matter. PCA (principal component analysis) and PLS (partial least squares) multivariate techniques identified the different reactivity of metals and supported the identification of the predominant controlling factors (soil textural features, pH, and total organic content). However, further research is needed to fully understand the complex nature of soilgroundwater interactions.

title: SLAQ: An SLA-Driven 6G O-RAN QoS Framework Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Noe Yungaicela-Naula, Vishal Sharma, Sandra Scott-Hayward
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: As 6G scenarios grow in complexity, network operators need an automated and optimized approach to managing Quality-of-Service (QoS) in the radio access network (RAN). Transitioning from resource-focused management to one that considers evolving operator intents is essential. This can be achieved by translating service-level agreement (SLA) intents into operational rules to ensure compliance and save costs. O-RAN introduced the RAN intelligent controller (RIC) and intelligent applications (xApps) to enhance the RAN operation. Furthermore, RAN slicing has been shown as the most promising method to provide O-RAN-based QoS in 6G. However, while existing methods optimize resources allocated per slice, they often overlook SLAs. This leads to suboptimal resource usage and outages when the system fails to meet target key performance indicators (KPIs). This work introduces SLAQ, an xApp designed to translate service operator requirements to optimize spectrum resource sharing. SLAQ monitors key performance metrics (KPMs) and employs deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to make decisions within the RAN. SLA policies are modeled and integrated into the xApp to optimize resource distribution while preventing SLA conflicts and outages. Our highly-detailed system-level simulations show that SLAQ effectively learns optimal actions, achieving high communication reliability, i.e., close to $99 \%$ for ultra-reliable low-latency communications.

title: DREAMS: Decentralized Resource Allocation and Service Management across the Compute Continuum Using Service Affinity
authors: Hai Dinh-Tuan, Tien Hung Nguyen, Sanjeet Raj Pandey
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Modern manufacturing systems require adaptive computing infrastructures that can respond to highly dynamic workloads and increasingly customized production demands. The compute continuum emerges as a promising solution, enabling flexible deployment of microservices across distributed, heterogeneous domains. However, this paradigm also requires a novel approach to resource allocation and service placement, as traditional centralized solutions struggle to scale effectively, suffer from latency bottlenecks, and introduce single points of failure. In this paper, we present DREAMS, a decentralized framework that optimizes microservice placement decisions collaboratively across different computational domains. At its core, DREAMS introduces agents that operate autonomously within each domain while coordinating globally through a Raft-based consensus algorithm and cost-benefit voting. This decentralized architecture enables responsive, privacy-preserving, and faulttolerant coordination, making it particularly suitable given the growing prevalence of multi-stakeholder scenarios across the compute continuum. In particular, within modern manufacturing environments, DREAMS achieves globally optimized service placements while maintaining high fault tolerance. Our evaluations further demonstrate that key coordination operations, such as Local Domain Manager (LDM) registration and migration voting, scale sub-linearly with the number of domains, confirming the efficiency and scalability of our proposed framework.

title: Research on Scale-Down Engine Design Method
authors: Pengyong Li, Jian Xie, Qingxiao Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: The gas generator serves as a critical component within the ejection system, and precise determination of its propellant performance is essential to ensuring optimal system functionality. For underwater ejection systems, accurate control of internal ballistic parameters during the ejection phase is paramount, as it enables the payload to achieve a stable initial trajectory upon water entry-a critical factor for successful operation in the underwater environment. As a chemical product, propellant undergoes individual testing during production and deployment to evaluate fundamental performance metrics such as burn rate and pressure exponent. However, obtaining an accurate assessment of the propellant's comprehensive performance remains challenging, thereby limiting effective control over internal ballistic behavior. This study presents a scaled-down engine design methodology, wherein reduced-scale engine tests are conducted to evaluate propellant performance. This approach facilitates the acquisition of comprehensive performance data at a significantly reduced cost, offering an efficient and practical means of assessing propellant characteristics.

title: Improved Lossless Compression based on Polar Codes
authors: Ling Liu, Jin Wang, Chao Chen, Lulu Ding, Zexuan Zhu, Baoming Bai
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: Polar codes have been proven to be capable of achieving the optimal rate for the lossless compression problem. However, their finite-length performance is not satisfactory due to the insufficient polarization effect. In this work, we combine source polarization with several entropy coding techniques to improve the compression efficiency while keeping the additional complexity negligible. In our framework, the standard encoding of polar codes can be treated as a pre-transform on the source data, and only a small proportion of the transformed data needs further compression thanks to the source polarization. We show that our framework is compatible with the mainstream entropy coding schemes such as Huffman coding, arithmetic coding, and asymmetric number system (ANS). To optimize performance, an iterative algorithm is proposed for the set partitioning of the transformed data. Simulation results show that the improved scheme is superior to the original polar source coding.

title: Robust Dynamic Coded Distributed Storage with Partially Storage Constrained Servers
authors: Chen Zhao, Haobo Jia, Zhuqing Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We consider the problem of Robust Dynamic Coded Distributed Storage (RDCDS) with partially storage constrained servers where the goal is to enable robust (resilient to server dropouts) and efficient (as measured by the communication costs) read and update operations, subject to the constraint where the storage at S out of N servers is limited by 1/K<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf> the size of the message. Building upon previously established converse arguments and achievability schemes by Jia et al., in this work we develop a set of new converse arguments and coding designs that enable us to completely characterize the fundamental limits of RDCDS with partially storage constrained servers, i.e., the minimum number of available servers for feasible update operation and the minimum communication costs for read and update operations across various server dropout scenarios.

title: Poster: Did I Just Browse A Website Written by LLMs?
authors: Sichang Steven He, Ramesh Govindan, Harsha V. Madhyastha
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 ACM Internet Measurement Conference
abstract: Increasingly, web content is automatically generated by large language models (LLMs) with little human input. We call this ''LLM-dominant'' content. Since LLMs plagiarize and hallucinate, LLM-dominant content can be unreliable and unethical. Yet, websites rarely disclose such content, and human readers struggle to distinguish it. Thus, we must develop reliable detectors for LLM-dominant content. However, state-of-the-art LLM detectors are inaccurate on web content, because web content has low positive rates, complex markup, and diverse genres, instead of clean, prose-like benchmark data SoTA detectors are optimized for.

title: Demo: Wide-coverage LE Audio via WiFi-BLE Cross-Technology Communication
authors: Lingang Li, ZiLong Liu, Yihao Zhang, Siyuan Peng, Zhirong Liu, Yongrui Chen, Zhijun Li
publish: Proceedings of the 31st Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking

title: Identifying the critical parameters of Late-onset Neonatal Sepsis using Statistical and Machine Learning Methods_supp1-3635468.pdf
authors: Dinesh Acharya U.
publish: N/A
abstract: Background: Late-onset neonatal sepsis (LONS), which occurs 72 hours after birth, remains a major cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality, particularly in resource-constrained settings. Traditional diagnostic methods are often delayed or infeasible in such environments. This study investigated statistical and machine learning approaches to enhance the early prediction of LONS and support timely clinical decision-making. Methods: Neonatal data from the first admission to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) within five days of delivery were retrieved from the MIMIC-III database. After preprocessing, a total of 83 variables were retained. Fifteen key features were identified based on their clinical relevance and one-way ANOVA across seven different sepsis criteria frameworks. Machine learning techniques such as extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost), light gradient boosting machine (LightGBM), and random forest were evaluated with and without applying SMOTE to correct class imbalance. Ensemble classifiers were developed, and their performance was assessed via 10-fold cross-validation and an independent test dataset. Results: Gradient boosting and LightGBM achieved an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) of 0.9269 and 0.9258, respectively, whereas random forest with SMOTE reached an AUROC of 0.9255. The final soft voting classifier, which combines the top three models, demonstrated robust performance, with an AUROC of 0.9271, an accuracy of 0.8521, and an F1 score of 0.7698. Conclusion: A machine learning–based ensemble approach using only 15 features can effectively predict LONS from clinical data within the first 24 hours of NICU admission. This data-driven model offers a scalable, real-time decision-support tool for neonatal care.

title: Inference-Time Noise Addition for Improving Adversarial Robustness of Audio Deepfake Detection System
authors: Inho Kim, Thien-Phuc Doan, Sanghyun Hong, Souhwan Jung
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: As artificial intelligence technology advances, the generalization performance of audio deepfake detection systems has improved rapidly and significantly. However, these systems still face substantial challenges when confronted with adversarial attacks. To address this issue, many studies have proposed defense methods against such attacks. Nevertheless, only a limited number of studies have focused on defenses in the context of audio deepfake detection. With the development of deep learning, deepfake detection methods are increasingly designed and deployed based on deep learning models. As a result, deepfake detection systems can be applied across various fields and are not restricted to specific data types or domains. Such approaches are referred to as ‘domain-independent’ defense methods and can be applied to a wide range of tasks, including adversarial training. However, they have limitations, such as requiring significant computing resources or potentially degrading original performance. In this paper, we propose Inference-Time Noise Addition (ITNA), an effective and efficient adversarial attack defense method that minimizes the original performance degradation. ITNA adds Gaussian noise once to the input audio sample during the inference phase. It is highly resource efficient, as it does not require additional training or separate AI components. Furthermore, ITNA minimizes performance degradation as much as possible and provides scalability that can be used with other defense methods. We provide a theoretical explanation of the effectiveness of ITNA and validate it through experimental results. Our experiments were conducted on the ASVspoof2021 DF evaluation (official deepfake audio dataset from the ASVspoof community), In-The-Wild (collected in real environments) and DSD-Corpus datasets (includes various synthesizer samples). And experiments results demonstrate the effectiveness of ITNA, reducing the average misclassification rate and the attack success rate of detection systems by 4.48% and 31.90%, respectively. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of ITNA through comparative experiments with alternative noise type and existing noise-based defense method.

title: Mathematical Model and Vector Control of SPMSM Considering Eddy Current and Hysteresis Effects Based on Vector Magnetic Circuit Theory
authors: Xinkai Zhu, Dajun Zhao, Ming Cheng, Wei Qin, Changhao Song, Zheng Wang, Wei Hua
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: The traditional mathematical models of surface-mounted permanent magnet synchronous motor (SPMSM) usually ignore the influences of the eddy current and hysteresis effects due to the fact that there is no appropriate parameter to quantitatively characterize these effects. However, with the increase of operating frequency of the SPMSM and switching frequency of the converter, their influences are becoming increasingly serious and have to be considered. The vector magnetic circuit (VMC) theory contains three basic magnetic circuit parameters, i.e., reluctance, magdutance, and hysteretance, which respectively characterize the magnetization, eddy current effect, and hysteresis effects in the magnetic circuit, and provide a new prospective for motor control to consider the eddy current and hysteresis effects. Therefore, based on the VMC theory, this paper establishes the mathematical model of the SPMSM by proposing a R-L coordinate transformation to consider eddy current and hysteresis effects in the iron core, but keep the d- and q- axis equations decoupled. Consequently, based on the proposed mathematical model, the novel id = 0 vector control of SPMSM is designed. Simulation and experimental results show that compared with the traditional id = 0 vector control, the novel id = 0 vector control has higher current control accuracy, better steady state and dynamic performances.

title: Identification and Prediction of Multiple Intelligence Patterns among University Students using Machine Learning for Personalized Learning and Instruction
authors: Sonia Corraya, Shamim AI Mamun, M. Shamim Kaiser
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Humans possess seven types of intelligence for learning. However, conventional educational systems mostly rely only on the Linguistic and Mathematical types. This narrow focus leaves other intelligences unrecognized and unutilized in learners’ learning processes. The main challenge lies in holistically addressing diverse intelligence levels in typical educational settings. Prior research isolated dominant intelligence traits for personalization, which lack objectivity and fail to utilize the full spectrum of learning potentials. The goal of this research is to identify and predict underlying learning patterns in university students, enabling addressing all types of intelligence holistically at the group level. To achieve this, a multi-algorithm framework integrating unsupervised and supervised learning is developed to analyze Multiple Intelligences profiles and associated learner parameters from the Learning Meta-Learning dataset. MI profiles capture all seven types of intelligences. K-Means clustering identified three unique and interpretable MI profile patterns, outperforming the Two-Step clustering algorithm. For prediction, CatBoost achieved 92.20% accuracy across seven algorithms, including Random Forest, Extra Trees, XGBoost, LightGBM, K-Nearest Neighbors, and HistGradientBoosting. By incorporating Explainable Artificial Intelligence through Shapley Additive Explanations and optimizing features, its accuracy improved to 93.66%. The identified Multiple Intelligences profile patterns offer actionable insights. Beyond the high-level guidelines for personalizing instruction outlined in this paper, they can inform various personalized educational approaches and support further research by providing a structured understanding of learner diversity and a predictive framework.

title: TP-IoAV: A Tri-Party Cloud Data Protection Scheme for Internet of Autonomous Vehicle Coupled With Chaotic Biometric Cryptography
authors: Zhenlong Man, Ze Yu, Jiahui Yu, Xiangfu Meng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: As driverless technology advances, an immense amount of data will be generated, shared, and used between vehicles, users, and the cloud. This includes road conditions, GPS data, biometric data, which raises significant privacy concerns. This paper presents a secure authentication protocol and privacy protection framework based on chaotic biological cryptography for data sharing and storage in the Internet of Autonomous Vehicles(IoAV) framework. A biometric key generator is designed using single-modal multi-fingerprint feature-level reconstruction, allowing users to generate personalized private key pools. This protects biometric data in the cloud while ensuring revocability. By incorporating a nonlinear control function into the traditional three-dimensional Rucklidge chaotic system, a 4D-Yoz hyperchaotic system is created, ensuring secure key distribution and adherence to the “one time pad” principle. To verify the effectiveness of the chaos creature password and ensure the security of cloud-stored images, proposes an image encryption-storage algorithm based on the “<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$L_{\infty } $</tex-math> </inline-formula>” metric and the semi-tensor product of the matrix, introducing the chaotic biological key. Experimental simulations and performance analysis show that this algorithm effectively secures image data in the Internet of Vehicles.

title: NV-PCAM: Non-Volatile Precharge-Free Content-Addressable Memory
authors: Oliver Caisaluisa, Esteban Garzón, Eduardo Holguín, Marco Lanuzza, Luis Miguel Prócel
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Content-addressable memories (CAMs) are a class of associative memories known for their capability to perform massively parallel comparisons between an input query pattern and the entire memory content. In the past decade, the increasing demand for high-performance and energy-efficient computing systems has generated significant interest in non-volatile CAMs (NV-CAMs) based on emerging non-volatile memory devices. In this work, we propose a novel non-volatile, precharge-free CAM (NV-PCAM) scheme based on double-barrier magnetic tunnel junctions (DMTJs). When compared to its counterparts, NV-PCAM presents competitive figures of merit in terms of area, speed, and energy efficiency, while also ensuring low search error rates. We also provide a complete class of voltage-divider-based NV-CAM cells for benchmark comparison. All schemes are designed and laid out using a 65 nm process and evaluated under Monte Carlo and process-voltage-temperature (PVT) simulations. Through Monte Carlo simulations, the proposed NV-PCAM demonstrates up to 81% and 85% lower search energy than NV-NOR and NV-NAND, respectively, as well as a 61% and 16% improvement in terms of search delay with a compact cell area footprint.

title: Minimum Time Boundary Stabilization of Linear Coupled First-Order Hyperbolic Systems With Repeated Eigenvalues Speed States
authors: Wei Sun, Jing Li, Liangyu Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: The primary focus of this paper is on first-order linear coupled one-dimensional hyperbolic systems with repeated eigenvalue speeds. By employing the backstepping method, a full-state feedback controller is designed to ensure its convergence to the zero equilibrium in minimum time. The traditional backstepping method leads to infinite control gains when applied to systems with repeated eigenvalue speeds. To overcome this challenge, we first decouple the repeated eigenvalue speed states and then design a simpler target system to eliminate the singularity. Finally, a simulation example is presented to validate the effectiveness of the results obtained.

title: Measurement of Brachial Local Pulse Wave Velocity for Non-Invasive Assessment of Endothelial Reactivity
authors: Nimmi Sudarsan, Navya Rose George, Kiran V. Raj, Dinu S. Chandran, P. M. Nabeel, Jayaraj Joseph
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Endothelial reactivity (ER) is a critical marker of vascular health and a predictor of cardiovascular risk. While ultrasound-based diameter measurements during flow-mediated dilation (FMD) remains the clinical standard for assessing ER, its limitations, including rater dependency and measurement variability, necessitate alternative approaches. In this study, we propose a novel sensor-based measurement methodology, that leverages local pulse wave velocity (PWV) at the brachial artery for endothelial reactivity assessment (ERA). Beat-to-beat local brachial PWV was measured using dual piezoelectric transducers (PWVP) through pulse signal processing and foot detection algorithm. The processed signal then underwent time-series analysis during the reactive hyperemia (RH) procedure for ERA. The approach was validated through two studies: (1) a repeatability and measurement validation study (n = 10), comparing baseline PWVP to ultrasound-derived PWV (PWVU), and (2) an intervention study (n = 40) evaluating the correlation between ERA and FMD during reactive hyperemia. PWVP showed strong agreement with PWVU (R² = 0.89, p < 0.0001), and higher intra-rater measurement repeatability (ICC = 0.91 vs. 0.87). Baseline PWVP exhibited a significant negative correlation with arterial diameter (R² = 0.71) and was higher in females (18.37%). ERA measured via PWVP was consistent across sessions (ICC > 0.85) and showed strong correlation with FMD (R² = 0.88). Notably, mean absolute ERA (34.62%) was higher than FMD (8.64%). These results demonstrate that local PWVP offers a robust and non-invasive approach to assess ER, serving as a practical alternative to ultrasound-based methods, with improved repeatability and strong physiological relevance. This methodology holds promise for scalable vascular health monitoring in clinical and research settings.

title: Mosaic Selections: Managing and Optimizing User Selections for Scalable Data Visualization Systems_supp1-3634649.pdf
authors: Jeffrey Heer
publish: N/A
abstract: Though powerful tools for analysis and communication, interactive visualizations often fail to support real-time interaction with large datasets with millions or more records. To highlight and filter data, users indicate values or intervals of interest. Such selections may span multiple components, combine in complex ways, and require optimizations to ensure low-latency updates. We describe Mosaic Selections, a model for representing, managing, and optimizing user selections, in which one or more filter predicates are added to queries that request data for visualizations and input widgets. By analyzing both queries and selection predicates, Mosaic Selections enable automatic optimizations, including pre-aggregating data to rapidly compute selection updates. We contribute a formal description of our selection model and optimization methods, and their implementation in the open-source Mosaic architecture. Benchmark results demonstrate orders-of-magnitude latency improvements for selection-based optimizations over unoptimized queries and existing optimizers for the Vega language. The Mosaic Selection model provides infrastructure for flexible, interoperable filtering across multiple visualizations, alongside automatic optimizations to scale to millions and even billions of records

title: Efficient Privacy-Preserving 5G Authentication and Key Agreement for Applications (5G-AKMA) in Multi-Access Edge Computing
authors: Awaneesh Kumar Yadav, An Braeken
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: The 5G Authentication and Key Management for Applications (AKMA) protocol is a 5G standard proposed by 3GPP in order to standardize the authentication procedure of mobile users towards applications based on the authentication of the user to the mobile network. As pointed out by several authors, the 5G-AKMA protocol inherently poses severe security issues, including privacy, unlinkability, ephemeral secret leakage and stolen device attacks. Also, the protocol does not offer perfect forward secrecy. In addition, the network operator is able to record all applications to which the user is subscribed and any outsider eavesdropping the communication channel is able to link requests to different applications coming from the same user. While the state of the shows that various protocols are proposed to solve the 5G-AKMA security issues, they are either vulnerable to severe attacks or are computationally extensive. In this paper, we provide a new version of the protocol able to solve these privacy issues in an effective manner. In addition, we also extend the protocol such that it can be used for communications in multiaccess edge computing (MEC) applications, taking into account handover procedures from one MEC server to another. The proposed protocol has been thoroughly compared to existing ones, revealing its efficiency in terms of communication, computation storage, and energy costs. The comparative analysis shows that the proposed 5G-AKMA reduces computational cost by 92%, communication cost by 74%, storage cost by 38%, and energy consumption cost by 58%. The security verification has been conducted using informal and formal methods (Real-Or-Random (ROR) and Scyther Validation tools) to ensure the protocol’s security. Additionally, we conduct a comparative analysis under an unknown attack scenario. Furthermore, the simulation is carried out using NS3.

title: DC-Diff: A Diffusion-Based Network for Panchromatic Sharpening With Cross-Domain Feature Guidance
authors: Bingyu Shi, Jian Xing, Zihan Jiang, Rui Yang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Panchromatic image enhancement aims to overcome the resolution limitations of satellite sensors by fusing multispectral (MS) and panchromatic (PAN) data. However, existing methods often overemphasize certain information, leading to distortion of local details or loss of global structure. To effectively integrate both global and local structural features while preserving the richness of spectral information, this paper proposes a self-supervised panchromatic sharpening network based on a denoising diffusion probabilistic model, named DC-Diff. The network introduces a cross-domain feature learning module that jointly learns spectral and spatial representations, serving as conditional guidance for the denoising prediction network. Additionally, a novel frequency-weighted adjustment module is proposed, which incorporates diffusion timestep factors to selectively process information from different frequency components. Experiments conducted on the GF-2, QuickBird, and WorldView-3 datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves excellent performance in spatial detail recovery, spectral fidelity, and fusion quality, showcasing its effectiveness and robustness across both reduced-resolution and full-resolution test sets. Ablation studies further validate the effectiveness of the proposed modules, highlighting the method's potential in remote sensing image fusion.

title: A Fast Parallel Decoder for LDPC Codes Suitable for Burst Errors in QKD Reconciliation
authors: Duarte Mateus, Ricardo Chaves
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) relies on quantum mechanics to enable secure communication, with the reconciliation phase playing an essential role in correcting discrepancies in shared keys caused by noise. Conventional Low-Density Parity-Check (LDPC) codes, while robust against random errors, often struggle with burst errors arising from localized noise sources in practical QKD implementations. To address this challenge, we introduce specialized uniform LDPC codes over Galois fields explicitly designed to correct burst errors effectively. We further present a highly efficient parallel decoder for these LDPC codes, operating within the complexity class NC (Nick’s Class), making it particularly suitable for GPU-based implementation. Our decoder provides guaranteed high-performance reconciliation as long as the number of burst errors remains below a designated threshold. Additionally, we discuss an extension to our decoding approach: when configured to handle higher error rates, the algorithm becomes a Las Vegas algorithm, introducing a small but controlled probability of failure. Finally, we propose a basic algorithm for generating these specialized LDPC codes and highlight prospective optimizations required for constructing larger matrices.

title: Distance-Based Loop-Free Routing with Positive and Negative Link Weights
authors: J.J. Garcia-Luna-Aceves, Morteza Moghaddassian, Charles Hsieh
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: An efficient approach to distance-based loop-free routing is introduced called THOR (Transitive Hop-Ordered Routing) that, in contrast to all prior distributed routing algorithms and routing protocols, works correctly in the presence of negative link weights. THOR is shown to provide loop-free routing and to converge to shortest paths within a finite time. THOR is compared with OSPF using the ns-3 simulator for the case of minimum-hop routing, and the simulation results show that the approach used in THOR leads to faster convergence and less signalling overhead.

title: Study on Modeling and Application of Thermodynamic Properties Library for Cryogenics Liquid Rocket Engine
authors: Ziyan Liu, Zhan Su, Yushan Gao, Lixiang Xing
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: To enhance the system-level simulation capability for the thermodynamic properties of cryogenic liquid rocket engines with high efficiency and precision, a thermodynamic properties library for common cryogenic propellants, including hydrogen, methane, and oxygen, was developed using the Modelica language based on the Helmholtz energy equation of state (EOS). The performance of three iterative methods-Broyden method with superlinear convergence, Newton method with quadratic convergence, and the modified Levenberg-Marquardt (LM) method with cubic convergence-was systematically evaluated in terms of solution time and number of iterations. To verify the adaptability of the developed thermodynamic properties library, steady-state heat transfer simulation program for hydrogen and transient heat transfer simulation program for methane cooling channels were established for cryogenic liquid rocket engine applications. The results indicate that the developed thermodynamic properties library exhibits high accuracy, with a maximum average relative error of no more than 0.89% compared to the NIST standard data. In engineering applications, the average relative error for hydrogen steady-state heat transfer simulations remained below 5.81%, while the average relative error for methane transient heat transfer simulation was controlled within 1.14%. Additionally, it was found that converges more easily in the two-phase and gas regions compared to the liquid and supercritical regions. The three iterative methods used in this study significantly reduced solution time compared to calling NIST data. Although Newton method had slightly more iterations than the cubic-convergence modified LM method, its simpler computational process in each iteration resulted in the shortest solution time, saving 49.2% of the time cost compared to calling NIST data.

title: Research on the Influence of Launch Velocity on Flow Field and Motion Characteristics of Underwater Vehicles in Wave Environment
authors: Jinyi Ren, Yao Shi, Shan Gao, Guang Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: During the water-exit process of an underwater-launched vehicle traversing the free surface, the collapse of cavitation envelopes adhering to the vehicle's shoulder generates significant unsteady hydrodynamic loads. This phenomenon is markedly intensified in a wave environment, where dynamic free-surface deformations and multiscale interactions within the cavitating flow field amplify flow complexity. This study employs the fifth-order Stokes wave model, integrated with the Volume of Fluid (VOF) multiphase flow framework and the Schnerr-Sauer cavitation model, to investigate the cavitation evolution characteristics and kinematic response of the vehicle during water exit under varying launch velocities and wave phase conditions. The findings reveal that a reduced cavitation number promotes the development of more pronounced cavitation bubble morphologies at the vehicle's shoulder. In a wave environment, the influence of wave phase on cavitation dynamics during water exit is accentuated, exacerbating the asymmetry of cavitation bubbles between the windward and leeward sides and altering the loci of bubble collapse and detachment. As launch velocity increases, the perturbative effects of the wave environment progressively diminish, leading to a consistent reduction in the vehicle's trajectory deviation and yaw angle. Notably, the mitigation of the yaw angle is more pronounced for vehicles exiting at the wave trough phase with increasing launch velocity.

title: Analysis and Comparison of Network Architecture Options for Camera-Based AOI Systems
authors: Matthias Baier, Dirk Henrici
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: Camera-based Automated Optical Inspection (AOI) systems are essential for quality assurance in industry. While optical and algorithmic improvements are well-studied, the role of network architecture in system latency is less explored. This paper analyzes how processing unit placement, network technologies, and HTTP versions affect transmission performance. Experiments show that software implementation has the greatest impact, with Public Cloud setups introducing considerable latency variability. The findings underline the value of local infrastructure and optimized software for reliable, low-latency AOI.

title: VeriBridge: Real-Time Cross-Chain Bridge Attack Detection through Static-Informed Graph Anomaly Learning
authors: Tuan-Dung Tran, Dinh Khang Nguyen, Quang Trung Do, Van-Hau Pham
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference On Cryptography And Information Security (VCRIS)
abstract: Cross-chain bridges, while critical for interoperability in the Web3 ecosystem, have become a primary target for exploits, accounting for over $4.3 billion in losses—nearly 40% of all value stolen in recent years. Existing security paradigms fail to address this threat adequately due to a fundamental trade-off between pre-deployment static analysis and real-time dynamic monitoring. Current security paradigms are trapped in a critical trade-off: pre-deployment static analysis lacks runtime context and suffers from high false-positives, while real-time dynamic monitoring is blind to the underlying source-code vulnerabilities that enable sophisticated attacks. This paper introduces VeriBridge, a novel framework that breaks this impasse. VeriBridge pioneers a synergistic fusion of static intelligence and dynamic graph learning. It enriches real-time transaction graphs with fine-grained vulnerability data extracted from static analysis, providing crucial security context to an unsupervised Graph Autoencoder. By learning a high-fidelity model of normal behavior, VeriBridge detects malicious transactions, including zero-day exploits, as significant deviations from this learned norm, identified by high reconstruction error. Evaluated on a comprehensive dataset of real-world attacks, including the Poly Network and THORchain exploits, VeriBridge achieves a 96% F1-score, demonstrating a new frontier in robust, real-time security for critical blockchain infrastructure.

title: Fire Scene-Oriented Multi-UAV Reconnaissance Task Scheduling: An Adaptive Differential Evolution-Enhanced DRL Approach
authors: Ling Li, Chenxu Huang, Zi'ang Liang, Yu'ang Yan, Haolin Tan, Dan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference of Mechanical Engineering on Aerospace (CoMEA)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), leveraging their high maneuverability, rapid deployment, and multi-modal operational capabilities, demonstrate unique advantages in fire scene reconnaissance and search-and-rescue missions. This study proposes an Adaptive Mutation-based Differential Evolution-enhanced Double-Layer Deep Reinforcement Learning (AMSDE-DL-DRL) framework to address collaborative task scheduling for multiple UAVs in fire emergency scenarios. The framework employs a hierarchical architecture that decouples task allocation and path planning: an upper-layer encoder-decoder policy network handles multi-UAV task allocation, while a differential evolution-optimized attention network in the lower layer conducts single-UAV path planning under maximum flight distance constraints to maximize executed tasks. An Interactive Training Strategy (ITS) integrating pretraining, reinforcement training, and alternating phases optimizes training efficiency. Experiments demonstrate that AMSDE-DL-DRL significantly outperforms OR-Tools in task completion rate and maintains robust generalization at hundred-task scales, with ablation studies confirming its effectiveness in balancing performance and training efficiency. This approach provides a novel solution for large-scale dynamic multi-agent collaboration challenges.

title: An Efficient Hybrid Key Exchange Mechanism
authors: Benjamin D. Kim, Vipindev Adat Vasudevan, Alejandro Cohen, Rafael G. L. D’Oliveira, Thomas Stahlbuhk, Muriel Médard
publish: 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW)
abstract: We present CHOKE, a novel code-based hybrid key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM) designed to securely and efficiently transmit multiple session keys simultaneously. By encoding n independent session keys with an individually secure linear code and encapsulating each resulting coded symbol using a separate KEM, CHOKE achieves computational individual security–each key remains secure as long as at least one underlying KEM remains unbroken. Compared to traditional serial or combiner-based hybrid schemes, CHOKE reduces computational and communication costs by an n-fold factor. Furthermore, we show that the communication cost of our construction is optimal under the requirement that each KEM must be used at least once.

title: Smart Implants: Biocompatible Implant Pulse Generator (IPG) Materials for IoT-Enhanced Medical Devices
authors: Auns Khaled, Dorsaf Omri, Taoufik Aguili
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC)
abstract: In this work, we conducted a detailed analysis of the EM-Biocompatibility of an Implant Pulse Generators (IPG) with an integrated antenna, focusing on the impact of different encapsulation materials. We present a compact 2.45 GHz implantable antenna designed for IPG in IoT healthcare systems. Hence, we investigate three biocompatible enclosure materials-gold, alumina, and polyimide-by performing full-wave simulations and Specific Absorption Rate (SAR) evaluations in a tissue-equivalent phantom. The antenna achieves a $-\mathbf{1 0 ~ d B}$ bandwidth of 100 MHz and a gain is worth up to -27.2 dB, while all materials maintain SAR levels below $7.9 * 10^{-11} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{kg}$ according to IEC62209. The results presented in this paper come from a comparative analysis of various encapsulation materials used in the design of implantable antenna capsules. Our study prove that the materials play a critical role in determining the electromagnetic behavior and biocompatibility of smart implant, directly impacting its safety and reliability within the in vivo environment.
